editionStmt.edition: This early release includes some 500 EEBO-TCP transcriptions of Early Modern plays that have undergone several routines to create an interoperable and algorithmically amenable corpus of Early Modern Drama. Many incompletely or incorrectly transcribed words have been corrected, including obvious printers' errors, but the text has not been proofread word by word. Each word in the text has been identified as a distinct token with its own xml:id and assigned to a lemma, a part of speech, and a standard spelling. Speech prefixes were mapped to unique speaker ID's as "who" attributes of sp elements. elements

respStmt.resp: Incompletely or incorrectly transcribed words were reviewed and in many cases fixed by
respStmt.name: Nayoon Ahn

respStmt.resp: Tokenization and linguistic annotation using MorphAdorner and NUPOS 2.0 were provided by
respStmt.name: Philip R. Burns

respStmt.resp: With the help of Thomas L. Berger's Index of Characters in Early Modern English Drama Printed Plays, 1500-1660 speech prefixes were mapped to unique "who" attributes of sp elements by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

respStmt.resp: A provisional, rudimentry, and algorithmically produced castlist was added as a new div in the back listing each role with their number of speeches sorted from high to low by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

respStmt.resp: Project co-ordination and review of textual changes and linguistic annotation by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

titleStmt.title: Your fiue gallants As it hath beene often in action at the Black-friers. Written by T. Middleton.
Your five gallants
Your five gallants.
titleStmt.author: Middleton, Thomas, d. 1627.

publicationStmt.publisher: [By George Eld] for Richard Bonlan, dwelling at the signe of the Spred-Eagle, right ouer-against the great north dore of Saint Paules Church,

div.p: As it hath been often in action at the Blackfriars.
Imprinted at London for Richard Boulan, dwelling at the sign of the spread-eagle, right over-against the great North door of saint Paul's church.

div.stage: Presenter or prologue, passing over the stage, the bawde-gallant, with three wenches gallantly attire, meets him the whore-gallant, the pocket-gallant, the cheating-gallant, kiss these three wenches and depart in a little whisper and wanton action: now for the other the broker-gallant, be sits at home yet I warrant you, at this time of day, summing up his pawns, hactenus quasi inductio, a little glimpse giving.

sp.p: Is your pawn good and sound sir?
I'll pawn my life for that sir;
Place yourself there then, I will seek to prefer it presently: my master is very jealous of the pestilence; marry the pox sits at meat and meal with him.

sp.speaker: Frip.
sp.p: Lent the fifth day of September to mistress Onset upon her gown, taffety petticoat with three broad silver laces, three pound fifteen shillings.
Lent to justice Cropshin upon both his velvet jackets, five pound ten shillings.
Lent privately to my lady Newcut, upon her gilt casting-bottle, and her silver lye-pot, fifty five shillings.
Sir.

sp.speaker: Frip.
sp.p: Lent to sir Oliver needy upon his taffety cloak, beaver hat, and perfumed leather-jerkin, 6. pound 5. shillings.
May it please your worship —

sp.speaker: Frip.
sp.p: Lent to master Andrew Lucifer, upon his flame-coloured doublet, and blue taffeta-hose — top the candle sirrah, methinks the light burns blew-when came that suit in.
'Thas lain above the year now?

sp.speaker: Frip
sp.p: Fire and brimstone, cut it out into matches, the white linings will serve for tinder.

And with little help sir, they are almost black enough
already? — sir here's another come with a pawn;

sp.speaker: Frip.
sp.p: Keep him aside awhile ▪ and reach me hither the bill of the last week;
T●●●●ere at hand sir?

sp.speaker: Frip.
sp.p: Now sir what's your pawn?
The second part of a gentlewoman's gown sir, the lower half I mean;

sp.speaker: Frip.
sp.p: I apprehend you easily, the breeches of the gown!
Very proper, for she wears the doublet at home, a guest that lies in my house sir; she looks every hour: for her cousin out a'th' country.

sp.speaker: Frip.
sp.p: O her cousin lies here a may mistake in that? my friend of what parish is your pawn?
Parish why? Saint Clement's sir, - I'll come to you presently,

sp.speaker: Frip.
sp.p: What parish is your pawn my friend. Saint brides 5. Saint Dunstan's none; saint Clement's 3. 3. at Clements, away with your pawn sir, your parish is infected, I will neither purchase the plague for six pence in the pound, and a groat bill money, nor venture my small stock into contagious parishes: you have your answer fare-you-well, as fast as you can sir.
The pox arrest you sir at the suit of the suburbs.

sp.speaker: Frip.
sp.p: I welcome, welcome.
For I think plague scorns your company.

sp.speaker: Frip.
sp.p: I rank with chief gallants, I love to smell safely: lent in the vacation to master proctor upon his spiritual gown, 5. angels; and upon his corporal doublet, 15. shillings. sum 3. pound 5. shillings.
Sir.

sp.speaker: Frip.
sp.p: Now sir.

div.stage: Enter his man bringing a trunk.

sp.p: Here's one come in with a trunk of apparel.

sp.speaker: Frip.
sp.p: Whence comes it?
From saint Martin's in the field.

sp.speaker: Frip ▪
sp.p: Saint Martin's in the field, — saint Mary Maudlin 2. Saint Martin's none, here's an honest fellow, let him appear sir.
You may come near sir,

sp.speaker: Frip.
sp.p: O welcome, welcome what's your pawn sir?
Faith a gentlewoman's whole suit sir.

sp.speaker: Frie.
sp.p: Whole suit? 'tis well.
A poor kind soul, troubled with a bad husband; one that puts her to her shifts here.

sp.speaker: Frip.
sp.p: He puts her from her shifts methinks when she is fain to pawn her clothes?
Look you sir, a fair satin gown; new taffety petticoat.

sp.speaker: Frip.
sp.p: Stay, this petticoat has been turned?
Often turned up and down and you will, but never turned sir.

sp.speaker: Frip.
sp.p: Cry you mercy indeed:
A fine white beaver, pearl-band; 3. falls, I ha' known her have more in her days.

sp.speaker: Frip.
sp.p: Alas and she be but a gentlewoman of any count or charge, 3. faults are nothing, in these daies-know that; tut the worlds changed, gentlewoman's faults stand upright now, no sin but has a bolster, that it may lie at ease: well what do you borrow of these sir?
Twelve pound and you will sir.

sp.speaker: Frip.
sp.p: How?
They were not hers for twenty.

sp.speaker: Frip.
sp.p: Why so: our pawn is ever thrice the value of our money unless in plate and jewels, how should the months be restored and the use else? we must cast it for the twelvemonth , so many pounds, so many months, so many eighteen pences, than the use of these eighteen pences, than the want of the return of those pounds, all these must be laid together, which well considered, the valuation of the pawn had need to sound treble: can six pound pleasure the gentlewoman.
It may please her, but like a man of threescore in the limbrest degree.

sp.speaker: Frip.
sp.p: I have but one word more to say in't, twenty nobles is all and the utmost that I will hazard upon't.
She must be content with't, the less borrowed the better paid, come.

sp.speaker: Frip.
sp.p: Arthur?
At hand sir.

sp.speaker: Frip
sp.p: Tell out twenty nobles, and take her name in a bill?
I'm satisfied sir?

sp.speaker: Frip.
sp.p: Welcome: good saint Martin's in the field, welcome, welcome, I know no other name?

sp.speaker: Prim.
sp.p: What so hard at your prayers?

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.p: A little sir, summing up my pawns here: what master Primero? is it you sir gallant; and how does all the pretty sweet ladies, those plump, kind, delicate blisses; ha? whom I kiss in my very thoughts: how do they gallant?

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.p: Why gallant? if they should not do well in my house, where should it be done boy, have I not a glorious situation?

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.p: O a gallant receipt, violet air, curious garden, quaint walks, fantastical arbours, three backdoors and a coachgate, nay thou'rt admirably seated, little furniture will serve thee, thou'rt never without movables.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.p: I praise my stars; ah the goodly virginities that have been cut up in my house, and the goodly patrimonies that have lain like sops in the gravy, and when those sops were eaten, yet the meat was kept whole for another, and another, and another, for as in one pie twenty may dip their sippits, so upon one woman forty may consume their patrimonies.

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.p: Excellent, master Primero?

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.p: Well, I'll pray for women while I live, they're the profitablest fools, I'll say that for 'em, a man can keep about his house the pretiest kind fowl, so tame, so gentle e en to strangers, hands, so soon familiar, suffer to be touched, of those they never saw twice: the doves not like 'em.

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.p: Most certain, for that's honest; but I have a suit to you?

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.p: And so have I to you.

lg.l: That happens well,
Grant mine and I'll grant yours?

sp.speaker: ●ri.
sp.p: A match.

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.p: Make me perfect in that trick that got you so much at primero.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.p: O for the thread tied at your partners leg: the twitch?

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.p: I that twitch and you call't so.

lg.l: That secret twitch got me five hundred pound,
Ere 'twas first known and since I ha' sold it well
Five hundred pound laid down shall not yet buy,
the fee simple of my twitch I would be here with't,
'Twas a blessed invention, I had been a beggar many a lousy year
But for my twitch. It was the prettiest twitch?
Many over-cheated gulls, have fatted
Me with the bottom of their patrimonies
E'en to the last soap, gaped while I fed 'em;
Who now live by that art that first undid 'em.
But I must swear you to be secret, close,

sp.speaker: Frip.
sp.p: As a maid, at ten.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.p: Had you sworn but two years higher I would here ha' believed you.

lg.l: Nay I let twelve alone,
For after twelve has struck, maids look for one.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.p: I look for one too and a maid I think.

sp.speaker: Frip.
sp.p: What, to come hither?

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.p: Sure she follows me? A pretty fat eyed wench, with a Venus in her cheek, did but raiment smile upon her, she were nectar for great dons, boy and that's my suit to thee.

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.p: And that's granted already: of what volume is this book, that I may fit a cover to't?

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.p: Faith neither in folio, nor in decimo sexto, but in octavo between both, a pretty middle sized trug.

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.p: Then I have fitted her already: in my eye i'faith: here came a pawn in e'en now will make shift to serve her as fit, look you sir gallants, satin, taffety, beaver, fall and all.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.p: Is it new.

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.p: New? you see it bears her youth as freshly, —

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.p: A pretty suit of clothes i'faith; — but put case the party should come to redeem 'em of a sudden?

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.p: Puh then your wits sickly, have not I the policy think you to seem extreme busy and defer 'em till the morrow, against which time that pawn shall be secretly fetched home, and another carried out to supply the place.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.p: I like thy craft well there.

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.p: A general course, o frippery is an unknown benefit sir gallant!

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.p: And what must I give you for the hire now i'faith.

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.p: And for both those we'll fit it.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.p: I if the devil be not in't, make halt:

sp.speaker: Fri.

lg.l: I follow straight, vanish thou fog, and sink beneath our brightness,
Abashed at the splendour of such beams:
We scorn thee, base eclipser of our glories,
That wouldst have hid our shine from mortals' eyes,
Now gallants, I am for you, I and perhaps before you ▪
You can appearce but glorious from yourselves,
And have your beams but drawn from your own light,
But mine from many, many make me bright.

sp.p: Here's a diamond that sometimes gracest the finger of a countess, here sits a ruby that near lines blushing for the party that pawned it: here a saphire, oh providence and fortune! my beginning was so poor, I would fain forget it, and I take the only course, for I scorn to think on't. Slave to a trencher: observer of a saltseller, privy to nothing, but a close-stool, or such unsavoury secret: but as I strive to forget the days of my serving, so I shall once remember the first step of my raising, for having hardly raked five mark together, I rejoiced so in that small stock, which most providently I ventured by water to Blackwall, among fishwives, and in small time, what by weekly return, and gainful restitution it rise to a great body, beside a dish of fish for a present, that stately preserved me a sevennight: nor ceased it there but drew on greater profit, for I was held religious by those that do profess like abstinence, and was full often secretly supplied, by charitable Catholics, who censured me sincerely abstinate, when merely I for hunger nor for zeal, eat up the fish, and put their alms to use ha!, ha ha; but those times are run out, and for my sake, zealous dissemblance has since fared the worse; — let me see now, whose cloak shall I wear today to continue change,
O — Arthur.
Here sir.

sp.speaker: Frip
sp.p:
Bring down sir Oliver Needies taffeta cloak. And beaver hat, I am sure he is fast enough? And Andrew ●●cifers rapier and dagger, in the knight's ●ard, with the embossed girdle and hangers, for he's in his third sweat by this time, sipping of the doctor's bottle, or picking the ninth part of a rack of mutton dry
roasted, with a leash of nightcaps on his head like the Pope's triple crown, and as many pillows crushed to his back, with o the needles, for he got the pox of a se●ster, and it pricked so much more naturally, — quick Arthur quick, now,

lg.l: To the deceased knight's daughter
Whom many gallants sue to, I amongst many: for
Since impudence gains more respect than virtue,
And come them blood which few can now deny,
Who're your chief gallants, then but such as I.

div.stage: Enter misters Katherine with Fitsgrave a gentleman.

lg.l: You do your beauty's injury, sweet virgin,
To lose the time they must rejoice in youth:
There's no perfection in a woman placed
But wastes itself though it be never wasted,
Then judge your wrongs yourself.
Good master Fitsgrave?
Through sorrow for the knight my father's death,
(Whose being was the perfections of my joy:
And crown of my desires,) I cannot yet,
But forcedly, on marriage fi●e my heart,
Yet heaven forbid I should deject your hopes
Conceive not of me so uncharitably,
I should belie my soul if I should say,
You are the man I never should affect:
I understand you thus far, you're a gentleman
Whom your estate and virtues may command
To a far worthier breast, than this of mine,
O cease, I dare not hear such blasphemy,
What is without you worthy, I neglect,
In you is placed the worth that I respect:
Vouchsafe unequalled virgin whereon I justly kept,
Accept this worthless favour from your servant's arm, the hallowed beads,
The true and perfect number of my sighs.

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.p: Mine cannot equal yours, yet in exchange, accept and wear it for my sake.

sp.speaker: Fitsg.
sp.p: Even as my I'll rate it?

sp.speaker: Goldst.
sp.p: Heart? Fitsgrave in such bosom single-loves?

div.stage: Enter five gallants at the farther door.

sp.speaker: Pursnet
sp.p: So close, and private with her?

sp.speaker: Taylb.
sp.p: Observe hem, he grows proud and bold?

sp.speaker: Frip.
sp.p: Why was not this a general meeting?

sp.speaker: Prim.
sp.p: By her own consent, death how I could taste his blood?

sp.speaker: Kath.
sp.p: See, the gentlemen, at my request do all present themselves?

lg.l: Manifold blisses wait on her desire,
Whose beauty and whose mind so many honour?
I take your wishes thankfully? — kind gentlemen!
All here assembled, over whose long suits,
I near insulted,
Not like that common sickness of our sex,
Grew proud in the abundance of my suitors,
Or number of the days they sued unto me.
Dutiful sorrow for my father's death,
Not wilful coyness hath my hours detained
So long in silence:
I'm left to mine own choice, so much the more
My care calls on me if I err through love,
'Tis I must chide myself, I cannot shift
The fault unto my parents, they're at rest,
And I shall sooner err through love, than wealth.

sp.speaker: Goldst.
sp.p: Good.

sp.speaker: Pursnet
sp.p: Excellent.

sp.speaker: Taylb.
sp.p: That likes me well?

sp.speaker: Prim.
sp.p: Hope still.

lg.l: And my affections do pronounce you all ▪
Worthy their pure and most entire deserts,
Yet they can choose but one,
Nor do I dissuade any of his hopes,
(Because my heart is not yet thoroughly fixed,
On marriage, or the man,)
But crave the quiet respite of one month,
The month unto this night, against which time,
I do invite you all to that election,
which on my unstained faith, and virgin promise,
Shall light amongst no strangers, but yourselves:
May this content you?

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Glad, and content.

lg.l: 'Tis a good time to leave,
Till then, commend us to your gentlest thoughts.

div.stage: They look scuruily upon Fitsgrave, and he upon them. The boy in a corner, with his master pocket-gailant.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Enough.

sp.speaker: Fits.
sp.p: Ough.

sp.speaker: Boy
sp.p: Hist, master hist.

sp.speaker: Pursnet
sp.p: Boy? how now?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Look you sir.

sp.speaker: Pursnet
sp.p: Her chain of pearl.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: I specked it away fi●ely.

lg.l: Active boy, thy master's best revenue, his life and soul
Thou keepest 'em both together? whip, away,
Fall back, fall belly, I must be maintained,
Hope is no purchase, nor care I if I miss her, why I rank
In this design with gallants, there's full cause
Policy invites me to it, 'tis not for love, or for her sake alone:
It keeps my state suspect●e●le and unknown.
Their looks run through, and through me, and the st●●gs
Of their snake-hissing whispers pierced my hearing:
They're mad she graced me with one private minute,
Above their fortunes, I have observed 'em often,
Most spitefully aspected towards my happiness,
Beyond all others: but the ● use I know not,
A quiet month the virgin has enclosed
Unto herself: suitors stand without till then,
In which space cunningly I'll wind myself,
Into their bosoms. I have bethought the shape,
Some credulous scholar, easily infected
With fashion ▪ time, and humour. unto such
Their deepest thoughts, will like to wanton fishes,
Play above water, and be all parts seen:
For since ▪ at their envy pi●es I'll see
Whether their lives from touch of blame sit free.

sp.speaker: Goldst.
sp.p: I seldom saw so few here, you shall have 'em sometimes in every corner of the house, with their viols betwixt their legs, and play the sweetest strokes 'twould e'en filch your soul almost out of your bosom.

sp.speaker: Fitsg.
sp.p: Pax on't: we spoil ourselves for want of these things at university?

sp.speaker: Goldst.
sp.p: You have no such natural happiness, let's draw near,

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.p: Gentlemen you are all most respectively welcome:

sp.speaker: Goldst.
sp.p: We are bold and insatiate suitors sir to the breath of your music, and the dear sight of those ladies.

lg.l: And what our poor skill can invite you to,
You are kindly welcome: you must pardon 'em gentlemen,
Virgins and bashful, besides new beginners,
'Tis not a whole month since they were first entered.

sp.speaker: Goldst.
sp.p: Seven year in my knowledge ▪

lg.l: They blush at their very lessons, they will not endure,
To hear of a stop, a prick, or a semiquaver,

sp.speaker: 1. Curti.
sp.p: Oh out upon you:

lg.l: La I tell you, you'll bear me witness gentlemen,
If their complaints come to their parents ears,
Their words of art, I teach 'em naught but art.

sp.speaker: Goldst.
sp.p: Why 'tis most certain.

sp.speaker: Bung.
sp.p: For all scholars know, that musica est ars.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: O beastly word?

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.p: Look to the ladies, gentlemen;

sp.speaker: Goldst.
sp.p: Kiss again?

sp.speaker: Pursnet
sp.p: Come another?

sp.speaker: Taylb.
sp.p: This a good interim?

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.p: What have you done sir?

sp.speaker: Bung.
sp.p: Why? what have I done,

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.p: Saw you their stomachs queasy, and come with such gross meat!

sp.speaker: Bung.
sp.p: Why is't not latin sir,

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.p: Latin? Why then let the next to't be latin too:

sp.speaker: Pursnet
sp.p: So enough?

sp.speaker: Goldst ▪
sp.p:
Nay I can assure you thus far, I that never knew the
language have heard so much that ars, is latin for art, and it 'May well be too, for there's more art in't now a day's than ever was:

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.p: Is't possible ▪ I am sorry than I have followed it so far.

sp.speaker: 1. Curti.
sp.p: A scholar call you him,

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.p: Music must not jar; the offence is satisfied, come to the song, begin sir.

div.stage: The song, and he keeps time, shows several humours and moods: the boy in his pocket nims away fitsgraves jewel here, and exit.

sp.speaker: Bung.
sp.p: Not a whole month since you were entered ladies?

sp.speaker: Fitsg.
sp.p: None that shall see their cunning will believe it,

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.p: It is no affliction gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Bung.
sp.p: I care not much i'faith, if I write down to my father presently, to send up my sister in all haste, that I may place her here at this music school.

sp.speaker: Ne●●.
sp.p: Slid 'tis the fool my cousin, I would not for the value of three recreations he had seen me here?

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.p: How like you your new prize;

sp.speaker: Prip.
sp.p: Pray give me leave, I have not yet sufficiently admired her

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.p: My wits must not stand idle, 'slife he's in a sick trance?

lg.l: A cheat or two among these mistresses,
Would not be ill bestowed, I affect none,
But for my prey such are their affections,
I know it, how could drabs and cheaters live else,
Then since the world rolls on dissimulation,
I'll be the first dissembler.
Prithee love, comfort, choice, my only wish in thee
I am confined, deny me any thing a slight chain of pearl,

sp.speaker: Pursnet
sp.p: Nay an't be but slight —

lg.l: Being denied,
I prize it slight; but given me by my love,
Light shall not be so dear unto my eye;
Mine eye unto the body as the gift,
How have I power to deny this to you,
That command all my fortunes are thy servants,
and thou the mistress both of them and me.

sp.speaker: 1 Curt.
sp.p: The truest that ere breathed.

lg.l: To a gentleman,
That thus so long and has so sincerely loved you,
As I myself, ne'er was less pity shown.

sp.speaker: 2. Curt.
sp.p: Why I never was held cruel.

sp.speaker: Goldst.
sp.p: But to me.

sp.speaker: 2. Curt.
sp.p: Nor to you.

sp.speaker: Goldst.
sp.p: Go too, 'thas scared you much,

lg.l: I'm sorry your conceit is so unkind,
To think me so.
When had I other argument,
I've often tendered you my love and service,
And that in no mean fashion:
Yet were you never that requ●tefull mistress,
That graced me with one favour,
Slight, not so much as such a pretty ring, pax on't,
T'as almost broke my heart.

sp.speaker: 2. Curt.
sp.p: Has taken it off, 'sfoot master Bouser,

sp.speaker: Goldst.
sp.p: Nay where a man loves most, there to be scanted.

sp.speaker: 2. Curt,
sp.p: My ring, come, come.

lg.l: What reckon I a satin gown or two,
If she were wise.

sp.speaker: 2, Curt.
sp.p: Life my ring sir, come.

sp.speaker: Goldst.
sp.p: Have you the face i'faith.

sp.speaker: 2. Curt.
sp.p: Give me my ring.

sp.speaker: Goldst.
sp.p: Prithee hence, by this light you get none on't.

sp.speaker: 2. Curt.
sp.p: How?

lg.l: I hold your favours of more pure esteem,
Than to part from 'em, faith I do,
Howe'er you think of me.

sp.speaker: 2. Curt.
sp.p: Push, pray sir,

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Hark you, go too, you have lost much by unkindness, go your ways.

sp.speaker: 2. Curt.
sp.p: 'Sfoot.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: But yet there's no time past, you may redeem it.

sp.speaker: 2. Curt.
sp.p: Come, I cannot miss it i'faith; beside the gentleman that bestowed it on me ▪ swore to me it cost him twenty nobles.

lg.l: Twenty nobles ▪ pox of twenty nobles,
But you must cost me more, you pretty villain,
Ah you little rogue.

sp.speaker: 2. Curt.
sp.p: Come come, I know you're but in jest,

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: In jest no you shall see.

lg.l: No way will get it.
As good give it him now, and hope for somewhat.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: I ru● love made jest.

lg.l: I did but try thy faith, how fast thou'dst hold it,
Now I see a woman may venture worthy favours to thy trust,
And have 'em truly kept, and I protest, had I drawn't from thee,
I should ne'er ha' loved thee, I know that.
Sfoot I was ne'er so wronged in my life,
Think you I am in jest with you, what with my love?
I could find ●●ghter subjects you shall see,
And time will show, how much you injure me.
The ring were't thrice worth I freely give,
For I know you will requite it.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Will I live.

sp.speaker: 2. Curt.
sp.p: Enough.

lg.l: Why this was well come off now,
Where's my old servingman? not yet returned,
O here he peeps: now sirrah?

sp.p: May it please your worship — they're done artificially i'faith boy.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Both the great beakers.
Both lad.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Just the same size.
I and the marks as just.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: So fall off respectively now.
My lord desires your worship of all love.

lg.l: His lordship must hold me excused till morning,
I'll not break company tonight ,
Where sup we gallants?

sp.speaker: Pursnet
sp.p: At Man-maid.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: S●p there who list, I have forsworn the house.
Serving. For the truth is this plot must take effect ●t mitre.

sp.speaker: Goold.
sp.p: Faith I'm indifferent.

sp.speaker: Bung.
sp.p: So are we gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Pursnet
sp.p: Name the place master Goldstone.

lg.l: Why the mitre in my mind,
For neat attendance, diligent boys and, push, excels it fair.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Agreed, the mitre then: boy, some goodness towards, the boys whipped away.

sp.speaker: Fitsg.
sp.p: The jewel, heart the jewel.

sp.speaker: Goldst.
sp.p: How now sir? what moved you?

lg.l: Nothing sir, a spice of poetry, a kind a fury,
A disease runs among scholars.

sp.speaker: Goldst.
sp.p: Mass it made you stamp.

lg.l: Who, till make some stamp and stare, make a strange noise,
Curse swear, beat tire-men, and kick players boys,
The effects are very fearful.

sp.speaker: Pursnet
sp.p: Bless me from't.

sp.speaker: Fitsg.
sp.p: O you need not fear it sir — hell of this luck.

sp.speaker: Goldst.
sp.p: Hark, he's at it again.

lg.l: Some pageant plot, or some device for the tiltyard:
Disturb him not.

sp.speaker: Fitsg.
sp.p: How can I gain her love, when I have lost her favour.

sp.speaker: Goldst.
sp.p: What money hast about thee?

sp.speaker: Purs.
sp.p: Look you sir, I must be fain to pawn a fair stone here, for ordinary expenses: a pox of my tenants, I give 'em twenty days after the quarter, and they cut out forty.

sp.speaker: Frip.
sp.p: Why you might take the forfeiture of their leases then.

sp.speaker: Gold
sp.p: I know I might, but what's their course? the rogues comes me up all together, with geese and capons, and petitions in pigs shouts, which would move any man i'faith, were his stomach never so great, and to see how pitifully the pullen will look, it makes me after relent, and turn my anger into a quick fire to roast 'em — nay touched and spare it not.

sp.speaker: Frip.
sp.p: 'Tis right, well, what does your worship borrow of this sir?

sp.speaker: Goldst.
sp.p: The stone's twenty nobles.

sp.speaker: Frip.
sp.p: Nay hardly.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: As I am a right gentleman.

sp.speaker: Frip.
sp.p: It comes near it indeed: well here's five pound in gold upon't.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: 'Twill serve, and the ring safe and secret,

sp.speaker: Frip.
sp.p: As a virgin's.

lg.l: I wish no higher: what gallants ▪ are you constant,
Does the place hold?

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: The mitre.

sp.speaker: Goldst.
sp.p: Sir, in regard of our continued boldness, and trouble, (Which love to your music hath made us guilty of) shall we entreat your worship's company, with these sweet ladies, your professed scholars, to take part of a poor supper with myself and these gentlemen at the mitre.

sp.speaker: Frip.
sp.p: Pray master Primere.

sp.speaker: Pursnet
sp.p: I beseech you sir let it be so.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.p: O pardon me sweet gentlemen, the world's apt to censure, I have the charge of them, they're left in trust, they're virgins, and I dare not hazard their fames, the least touch mars 'em, and what would their right worshipful parents think, if the report should fly to them, that they were seen with gentlemen in a tavern.

lg.l: All this may be prevented, what serves your coach for,
They may come coached and masked.
You put me to't sir,
Yet I must say again, I fear the drawers,
And vintner's boys will be familiar with them,
And think 'em mistresses.
There are those places where respect seems slighter,
More censure is belonging to the mitre, you know that sir?

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.p: Gentlemen you prevail.

sp.speaker: Gol.
sp.p: We'll all expect you there.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.p: And we'll not fail.

sp.speaker: Frip.
sp.p: The devil will ne'er dissemble with them so, as you for them.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Come sir.

sp.speaker: Frip.
sp.p: What else, let's go,

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.p: How cheer you sir?

lg.l: Faith like the moon, more bright,
Decreased in body ▪ but remade in light,
Here thou shalt share some of my brightness with me.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.p: By my faith they are comfortable beams sir.

lg.l: Come, where have you spent the time now from my sight,
I'm jealous of thy action.

sp.speaker: Taylb.
sp.p: Push I did but walk, a turn or two in the garden.

sp.speaker: 1. Curt.
sp.p: What made you there?

sp.speaker: Taylb.
sp.p: Nothing but cropped a flower.

sp.speaker: 1. Cur.
sp.p: Some woman's honour I believe.

sp.speaker: Taylb.
sp.p: Foh, is this a woman's honour.

lg.l: Much about one?
When both are plucked their sweetness is soon gone.

sp.speaker: Taylb.
sp.p: Prithee be true to me.

sp.speaker: 1. Cur.
sp.p: When did I fail.

sp.speaker: Taylb.
sp.p: Yet I am ever doubtful, that your sin.

lg.l: I do account the world but as my spoil, to adorn thee,
My love is artificial to all others,
But purity to thee, — dost thou want gold?
Here take this chain of pearl, supply thyself,
Be thou but constant, firm and just to me,
Rich heirs shall want, ere want come near to thee.

sp.speaker: Taylb.
sp.p: Upon thy lip I seal sincerity.

sp.speaker: 2. Cur.
sp.p: Was this your vow to me?

sp.speaker: Taylb.
sp.p: Pox, what's a kiss to be quite rid of her, she's sued so long I was ashamed of her, 'twas but her cheek I kissed neither, to save her longing.

sp.speaker: 2. Cur.
sp.p: 'Tis not a kiss I weigh.

lg.l: Had you weighed this,
T'ad lacked above five ounces of a true one:
No kiss that ere weighed lighter.

sp.speaker: 2. Cur.
sp.p: 'Tis thy love that I suspect.

sp.speaker: Taylb.
sp.p: My love, why by this, — what shall I swear by?

sp.speaker: 2. Cur.
sp.p: Swear by this jewel, keep thy oath, keep that ▪

sp.speaker: Tayl.
sp.p: By this jewel then, no creature can be perfect in my love, but thy ▪ dear self.

sp.speaker: 2. Cur.
sp.p: I rest.

sp.speaker: Tayl.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, let's laugh at 'em sweet soul.

sp.speaker: Novice
sp.p: Ay, they may laugh at me, I was a novice, and believed your oaths,

lg.l: Why what do you think of me, make i no difference,
Turn seven years prostitution, and seven days,
Why you're but in the wane of a maid yet:
You wrong my health in thinking I love them,
Do not I know their populous imperfections.
Why they cannot live till easter, let 'em show
The fairest side to'th world like hundreds more, whose clothes
E'en stand upright in silver, when their body,
Are ready to drop through 'em, such there be,
They may deceive the world, they ne'er shall me.
Forgive my doubts, and for some satisfaction were this ●ing,
From which I vow de near, but to thee, to part.

sp.speaker: Tayl.
sp.p: With which thou ever bindest me to thy heart.

lg.l: My pocket picked, this was no brothel-house,
A music school; damnation has fine shapes,
I paid enough for'th song, I have lost a jewel
To me more precious than their souls to them,
That gave consent to filch it, I'll hunt hard:
Wast time and money, trace and wheel about,
But I will find these secret mischiefs out-how now, what's he:
O a servant to my love, being thus disguised,
I'll learn some news, now sir; you belong to me.

sp.p: I do sir, but I cannot stay to say, so, nay good sir detain me not I am going in all haste to inquire or lay wait for a chain of pearl nimmed out of her pocket the fifth of November, a dismal day.

sp.speaker: Fitsg.
sp.p: Ha a chain of pearl sayest thou.
A chain of pearl sir, which one master Fitsgrave a gentleman and a suitor fastened upon her as a pledge of his love.

sp.speaker: Fitsg.
sp.p: Ha?

lg.l: Urge me no more I have no more to say,
Your friend Jeronimo bedlam.
Thou'rt a mad fellow indeed, some comfort yet,
That's hers is missing too, I feel my soul at much more ease: both stolen.
When griefs have partners they are better born.
O the parting of us twain,Enter wbore Gal.
Hath caused me mickle pain, and I shall ne'er be married,
Until I see my muggle again.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: Hist?

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.p: Ha.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: The nimble gentleman, in the celestial stockings.

lg.l: Has the best smock fortune, to be beloved of women?
Valle loo lo lille lo lilo, vallee loo lee lo lillo.

sp.speaker: Taylb.
sp.p: Vallee loo lo lillee lilo, vallee loo le lo lil'o.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: Ah sweet gentleman, he keeps it up stately.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.p: Well held i'faith sir — mass and now I remember too, I think you ne'er saw my little banqueting, box above, since I altered it.

sp.speaker: Taylb.
sp.p: Why have you altered that?

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.p: O divinely sir: the pictures are all new run over again.

sp.speaker: Taylb.
sp.p: Fie.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.p: For what had the painter done think you, drew me, Venus naked, which is the grace of a man's room you know, and when he had done, drew a number of oaken-leaves before her, had not lawn been a hundred times softer, made a better show, and been more gentlewoman like?

sp.speaker: Taylb.
sp.p: More ladylike, a great dea'e.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.p: Come, you shall see how 'tis altered now? I do not think but you'll like her.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.p: Where be your liveries?
They attend without.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.p: Go, call the coach! Gentlemen, you have excelled in kindness as we in boldness.

sp.speaker: Taylb.
sp.p: So you think amiss sir?

lg.l: Kind ladies we commit you to sweet dreams,
Ourselves unto the fortune of the dice, dice ho?

sp.speaker: 1. Cur.
sp.p: You rest firm mine.

sp.speaker: Taylb.
sp.p: E'en all my soul to thee.

sp.speaker: 2. Cur.
sp.p: You keep your vows.

sp.speaker: Tayl.
sp.p: Why do I breathe, or see?

sp.speaker: Novice
sp.p: Is your love constant.

sp.speaker: Tayl.
sp.p: I to none but these now gone, ay, now I love nor them nor thee, 'slife, I should be cloyed, should I love one in three.

sp.speaker: Purs.
sp.p: O here's master Bowser now.

sp.speaker: Fitsg.
sp.p: Save you sweet gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Taylb.
sp.p: Sweet master Bowser? welcome?

sp.speaker: Pursnet
sp.p: When come these dice.

sp.speaker: Pursnet
sp.p: Yet anon, anon sir.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.p: Hast thou shown art in 'em.
You shall be judge sir, here be the tavern beakers, and here peep out the fine alchemy knaves, looking like, well sir, most of our gallants, that seem what they are not.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.p: Peace villain, am not I in presence.
Why that puts me in mind of the jest sir.

sp.speaker: Goldst.
sp.p: Again, you quarter her.
Nay, compare 'em, and spare 'em not.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: The bigness of the bore, just the same size, the marks, no difference: away, put money in thy pocket, and offer to draw in upon the least occasion.
I am no babe sir.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Hist.
What's the matter now?

sp.speaker: Gold
sp.p: Give me a pair of false dice, ere you go.
Pax on't, you're so troublesome too, you cannot remember a thing before, if I stay a little longer, I shall be stayed anon.

sp.speaker: Vintner
sp.p: Here be dice for your worships.

sp.speaker: Pursnet
sp.p: O come, come.

lg.l: The vintner himself,
Ilo shift away these beakers by a slight.

sp.speaker: Vintner
sp.p: Master Goldstone?

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: How now you conjuring rascal?

sp.speaker: Vintner
sp.p: Bless your good worship, you're in humours methinks .

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Humours: say that again.

sp.speaker: Vintner
sp.p: I said no such word sir, — would I had my beakers out on's fingers.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: What's thy name vintner?

sp.speaker: Vintner
sp.p: Jack and please your worship.

sp.speaker: Gol.
sp.p: Turn knight like thy companions, scoundrel, live upon usury, wear thy gilt spurs at thy girdle for fear of slubbering.

lg.l: O no, I hope I shall have more grace than so sir:
Pray let me help your worship.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Cannot I push 'em together without your help?

sp.speaker: Vintner
sp.p: O I beseech your worship, they're the two standards of my house.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Standards, there lie your standards.

sp.speaker: Vintner
sp.p: Good your worship; I am glad they are out of his fingers, my wife shall lock 'em up presently, they shall see no sun this twelvemonth's day for this trick.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Let me come to the sight of your standards again.

sp.speaker: Vintner
sp.p: Your worship shall pardon me, now you shall not see 'em in haste I warrant ye.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: I do not desire't; ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Bow.
sp.p: Why master Goldstone?

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: I am for you gallants — master Boxeer cry you mercy sir, why supped you from us?

sp.speaker: Bou.
sp.p: Faith sir, I met with a couple of my fellow pupils at university, and so we renewed our acquaintance and supped together.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Fie, that's none of the newest fashion, I must tell you that master Bouser, you must never take acquaintance of any ath' university, when you are at London, nor any of London when you're at university you must be more forgetful i'faith, every place ministers his acquaintance abundantly.

sp.speaker: Bun.
sp.p: He tells you true sir.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: I warrant you here's a gentleman will ne'er commit such an absurdity.

sp.speaker: Bun.
sp.p: Who I, no, 'tis well known, if I be disposed, I'll forget any man in a sevennight, and yet look him in the face: nay let him ride but ten mile from me, and come home again, it shall be at my choice whether I'll remember him or no, I have tried that.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: This is strange sir.

sp.speaker: Bun.
sp.p: 'Tis as a man gives his mind too 't sir: and now you bring me in; I remember 'twas once my fortune to be cozened of all my clothes, and with my clothes my money; a poor shepherd pitying me, took me in, and relieved me.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: 'Twas kindly done of him i'faith,

sp.speaker: Bun.
sp.p: Nay you shall see now, 'twas his fortune likewise not long after, to come to me in much distress i'faith, and with weeping eyes, and do you think I remembered him.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: You could not choose.

sp.speaker: Bun.
sp.p: By my troth not I, I forgot him quite, and never remembered him to this hour.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: And yet knew who he was.

lg.l: As well as I know you i'faith —
'Tis a gift given to some above others.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: To fools and knaves they never miss on't.

sp.speaker: Bu.
sp.p: Does any make such a wonder at this; why alas 'tis nothing to forget others; what say you to those that forget themselves?

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Nay then to dice: come set me gallants, set.

sp.speaker: Frip
sp.p:
Ay, fall too 't gentlemen. I shall here some news from some of you anon: I have thou'rt to know which loose and ne'er look on; I'll be ready with all the worst money I can find
about me, Arthur!

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: Here sir.

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.p: Stand ready.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.p: Fear not me sir.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: These are mine sir.

sp.speaker: Frip.
sp.p: Here's a washt angel, it shall away: here's mistress Rose-noble has lost her maidenhead, cracked in the ring, shoe's good enough for gamesters, and to pass from man to man: for gold presents at dice your harlot, in one hour won and lost thrice, every man has a fling at her.

sp.speaker: ●ay.
sp.p: Again pax of these dice

sp.speaker: Bu.
sp.p: 'Tis ill to curse the dead sir.

sp.speaker: Purs. ▪
sp.p: Mew, where should I wish the pox, but among bones.

sp.speaker: Fitsg.
sp.p: He tells you right sir.

lg.l: I ne'er have any luck at these odd hands,
None here to make us fix — why master Frip.

sp.speaker: Frip.
sp.p: I am very well here I thank you sir, I had rather be telling my money myself, then have others count it for me; 'tis the scurviest music in the world methinks , to hear my money jingle in other men's pockets, I never had any mind to't i'faith.

sp.speaker: Tay.
sp.p: 'Slud play six or play four, I'll play no more.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: 'Sfoot you see, there's none here to draw in.
Rather than you should be destitute gentlemen, I'll play my ten pound, if my master's worship will give me leave.

sp.speaker: Purs.
sp.p: Come.

sp.speaker: Tay.
sp.p: He shall, he shall.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Pray excuse me gentlemen: ●soot how now goodman rascal, what? because you served my grandfather when he went ambassador, and got some ten pound by'th hand, has that put such spirit in you, to offer to draw in among gentlemen of worship, knave.

sp.speaker: Tay.
sp.p: Pray sir, let's entreat so much for once.

lg.l: 'Tis a usual grace i'faith sir,
You've many gentlemen will play with their men.

sp.speaker: Bung.
sp.p: I and with their maids to i'faith.

sp.speaker: Purs.
sp.p: Good sir give him leave.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Yes, come, and you be weary on't, I pray draw near sir.
Not so sir.

sp.speaker: Tayl.
sp.p: Come fool, fear nothing, I warrant toe, has given thee leave, stand here by me, come now, set round gentlemen, set,

sp.speaker: Pur.
sp.p: How the poor fellow shakes: throw lustily man.
At all gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Tayl.
sp.p: Well said i'faith.

sp.speaker: Pursnet
sp.p: They're all mine.

sp.speaker: Taylb.
sp.p: By my troth I am glad the fellow has such luck, it will encourage him well.
At my master's worship alone.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.p: Now sit slave?
At my master's worship alone.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.p: So, saucy rascal.
At my master's worship alone.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.p: You're a rogue and will be ever be one?
By my troth gentlemen at all again for once.

sp.speaker: Taylb.
sp.p: Take 'em to them boy, take 'em to thee, thou'rt worthy of 'em i'faith.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.p: Gentlemen faith I am angry with you, go and suborn my knave again me here; to make him proud and peremptory.

sp.speaker: Taylb.
sp.p: Troth that's but your conceit sir, the fellows an honest fellow and knows his duty, I dare swear for him.

sp.speaker: Pursnet
sp.p: Heart, I am sick already.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.p: Whether goes master —

sp.speaker: Pursnet
sp.p: Play on, I'll take my turn sir? — boy?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Master.

sp.speaker: Pursnet
sp.p: Pist? — a supply, carry't closely my little fooker, — how much —

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Three pound sir.

sp.speaker: Pursnet
sp.p: Good boy, — take out another lesson? how now gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Taylb.
sp.p: Devils in't did you ere see such a hand?

sp.speaker: Pursnet
sp.p: I set you these three angels.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: My master may set high? — for all his stakes are drawn out of other men's pockets.
As I said gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Pursnet
sp.p: Deuce ace.
At all your right worshipful worships.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Death and vengeance!

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.p: Hell, darkness,

sp.speaker: Taylb.
sp.p: Hold sir.

sp.speaker: Pursnet
sp.p: Master Goldstone.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Hinder me not sweet gentlemen — you rascal — I banish thee the board.

sp.speaker: Tayl.
sp.p: I'faith but you shall not sir?

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.p: Touch a die and thou dar'st, come you in with your lousy ten pound, you slave among gentlemen of worship, and win thirty at a hand.

sp.speaker: Taylb.
sp.p: Why will you kick again luck sir?

sp.speaker: Bung.
sp.p: As long as the poor fellow ventures the loss of his own money, who can be offended at his fortunes.
I have a master here? many a gentleman would be glad to see his man come forward aha.

sp.speaker: Pursnet
sp.p: Pray be persuaded sir:

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.p: 'slife, here's none cuts my throat in play but he I have observed it, an unluckily slave 'tis.

sp.speaker: Bung.
sp.p: methinks his luck's good enough sir.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.p: Upon condition gentlemen that I may ever bar him from the board hereafter I am content to wink at him.

sp.speaker: Pursnet
sp.p: Faith, use your own pleasure hereafter, has won our money now! come to'th table sir your master's friends with you.
Pray gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Taylb.
sp.p: The fiends in't I think, I left a fair chain of pearl at my lodging too, like an ass and ne'er remembered it; that would ha' been a good pawn now, speak what do you lend upon these master Frip? I care not much if you take my beaver hat too, for I perceive 'tis dark enough already, and it dos but trouble me here.

sp.speaker: Frip.
sp.p: Very well sir why now I can lend you 3. pound sir —

sp.speaker: Taylb.
sp.p: Prithee do't quickly then? ▪

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.p: There 'tis in six angels.

sp.speaker: Tayl.
sp.p: Very compendiously.

sp.speaker: Frip.
sp.p: Here Arthur, run away with these presently, I'll enter 'em into'th shop-book tomorrow. Item one gilt hatched rapier and dagger, with a fair embroidered girdle, and hangers, with which came also a beaver hat, with a correspondent band.

sp.speaker: Tayl.
sp.p: Push, i'faith sir your to blame, you have snibbed the poor fellow too much, he can scarce speak, he cleaves his words with sobbing.
Haff haff, haff, haff at all gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.p: Ah rogue, I'll make you know yourself.
At the fairest.

sp.speaker: Pursnet
sp.p: Out i'faith — two aces.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.p: I am glad of that, come pay me all these goodman cloak-bag:

sp.speaker: Pursnet
sp.p: Why are you the fairest sir?

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.p: You need not doubt of that sir — five. angels you scoundrel.
Fie ath' these dice, not one hand tonight , — there they go gentlemen at all i'faith.

sp.speaker: Purs.
sp.p: Pay all with 2. treas and a quater.

sp.speaker: Taylb.
sp.p: All curses follow 'em, pay yourselves withal, I'll pawn myself to't, but I'll see a hand tonight , not once hold in? here master Frip, lend me your hand, quick, quick, so.

sp.speaker: Frip.
sp.p: What do you borrow of this doublet now?

sp.speaker: Taylb.
sp.p: Ne'er saw the world three days.

sp.speaker: Frip.
sp.p: Go too, in regard your a continual customer, I'll use you well, and pleasure you with five angels upon't.

sp.speaker: Tayl.
sp.p: Let me not stand too long ith' cold for them:

lg.l: Had ever country gentleman such fortune?
All swooped away I'd, need repair to'th brokers,

sp.speaker: Taylb.
sp.p: If you be in that mind sir there sits a gentleman will furnish you upon any pawn, as well as the publickst broker of 'em all:

sp.speaker: Bung.
sp.p: Say you so sir, there's comfort in that i'faith.

sp.speaker: Frip.
sp.p: Item, upon his orange tawny satin doublet, five angels,

sp.speaker: Bung.
sp.p: But by your leave sir? next comes the breeches, —.

sp.speaker: Frip.
sp.p: O I have tongue fit for any thing —

sp.speaker: Bung.
sp.p: Saving your tail sir? 'tis given me to understand that you are a gentleman ith' hundred, and deal in the premises aforesaid.

sp.speaker: Frip.
sp.p: Master Bungler, master Bungler, you're mightily mistook, I am content to do a gentleman a pleasure for once, so his pawn be neat and sufficient.

sp.speaker: Bung.
sp.p: Why what say you to my grandfathers seal ring here

sp.speaker: Frip.
sp.p: I marry sir, this is somewhat like.

sp.speaker: Bung.
sp.p: Nay view it well, an ancient arms, I can tell you.

sp.speaker: Frip.
sp.p: What's this sir?

sp.speaker: Bung.
sp.p: The great codpiece with nothing in't.

sp.speaker: Frip.
sp.p: How?

sp.speaker: Bung.
sp.p: The word about it, partur iunt montes.

sp.speaker: Frip.
sp.p: What's that I pray sir?

sp.speaker: Bun.
sp.p: You promise to mount us.

sp.speaker: Frip.
sp.p: And belike he was not so good as his word.

sp.speaker: Bun.
sp.p: So it should seem by the story, for so our names came to be bunglers ▪

sp.speaker: Frip.
sp.p: A lamentable hearing that so great a house should shrink and fall to ruin.

sp.speaker: Pursnet
sp.p: Two quatres and yet lose it heart, boy? ▪ i'faith? what is't?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Five pound sir.

sp.speaker: Pursnet
sp.p: By my troth this boy goes forward well, ye shall see him come to his preferment ith' end!

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.p: Why how now, who's that gentlemen, a bargeman?

sp.speaker: Tayl.
sp.p: I never have any luck gallants, till my doublets off, I'm not half nimble enough, at this old finquanter drivelbeard:

sp.speaker: Purs.
sp.p: Your worship must pay me all these sir?

sp.speaker: Taylb.
sp.p: There, and feast the devil with 'em.

sp.speaker: Pursnet
sp.p: Hell gnaw these dice.

sp.speaker: Gol.
sp.p: What do you give over gallants.

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.p: Is't not time.

sp.speaker: Tayl.
sp.p: I protest, I have but one angel left to guide me home to my lodging.

sp.speaker: Gol.
sp.p: How much thinkst?

sp.speaker: Fulk.
sp.p: Some fourscore angels, sir.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.p: Peace, we'll join powers anon, and see how strong we are in the whole number, mass, yond guilt goblet stands so full in mine eye, the whoreson tempts me, it comes like cheese after a great feast, to digest the rest, he will hardly scape me i'faith I see that by him already; back for a parting blow now, ▪ boy?

sp.speaker: Vintner
sp.p: Anon anon sir:

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.p: Fetch a pennyworth of soft wax to seal letters.

sp.speaker: Vintner
sp.p: I will sir?

sp.speaker: Tayl.
sp.p: Nay had not I strange casting, thrice together, 2. quatres and a dews.

sp.speaker: Pursnet
sp.p: Why was not I as often haunted with two treas, and a quater:

sp.speaker: Vintner
sp.p: There's wax for your worship — anon, anon, sir.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.p: Screen me a little you whoreson old cross biter.

sp.speaker: Fu.
sp.p: Why what's the business? fill chiton h●b goblet.

sp.speaker: Pursnet
sp.p: And what has master Bowser lost?

sp.speaker: Bou.
sp.p: Faith not very deeply sir, enough for a scholar, some half a score royals.

sp.speaker: Pursnet
sp.p: 'Sfoot I have lost as many with spurs at their heels.

sp.speaker: Gol.
sp.p: Come gallants shall we stumble:

sp.speaker: Tayl.
sp.p: What's o'clock .

sp.speaker: Drawer
sp.p: Here's none on't Dick, the goblets carried down.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.p: Nay 'tis upon the point of three, boy, drawer, what's to be done sirs?

sp.speaker: Vintner
sp.p: All's paid, and your worships are welcome, only there's a goblet missing gentlemen, and cannot be found about house.

sp.speaker: Gold
sp.p: How a goblet:

sp.speaker: Pursnet
sp.p: What manner a one ▪

sp.speaker: Vintner
sp.p: A guilt goblet sir, of an indifferent size.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Sfoot I saw such a one lately.

sp.speaker: Vintner
sp.p: It cannot be found now sir.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Came there no strangers here?

sp.speaker: Vintner
sp.p: No sir.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: This a marvelous matter, that a goblet should be gone, and none but we in the room, the loss is mere all, here as we are; keep the door vintner.

sp.speaker: Vintner
sp.p: No I beseech your worship.

sp.speaker: Gol.
sp.p: By my troth vintner we'll have a privy search for this; what? we are not all one woman's children.

sp.speaker: Vintner
sp.p: I beseech ye gentlemen, have not that conceit of me, that I suspect your worships.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Tut, you are an ass; do you know every man's nature: there's a broker ith' company.

sp.speaker: Purs.
sp.p: 'Slife you have not stole the goblet, boy, have you?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Not I sir.

sp.speaker: Purs.
sp.p: I was afraid, — 'tis a good cause i'faith, let each man search his fellow, we'll begin with you.

sp.speaker: Tayl.
sp.p: I shall save somebody a labour gentlemen, for I'm half searched already.

sp.speaker: Purs.
sp.p: I thought the goblet had hung here i'faith — none here, nor here.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Seek about flower, — what was the goblet worth vintner.

sp.speaker: Vintner
sp.p: Three pound ten shillings sir no more.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Pox on't gentlemen, 'tis but angels a piece, it shall be a brace of mine, rather than I would have our reputations breathed upon by all comers, for you must think they'll talk on't in all companies; such a night, in such a company, such a goblet, sfoot it may grow to a gangrene in our credits and be incurable.

sp.speaker: Tayl.
sp.p: Faith I am content.

sp.speaker: Frip,
sp.p: So am I.

sp.speaker: Purs.
sp.p: There's my angel too.

sp.speaker: Gol ▪
sp.p:
So, and mine, I'll tell thee what, the missing of this goblet
has dismayed the gentlemen much.

sp.speaker: Vintner
sp.p: I am sorry for that sir.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Yet they send thee this comfort by me, if they see thee but rest satisfied, and depart away contented, which will appear in thy countenance; not three times thrice the worth of the goblet shall hang between them and thee, both in their continual custom, and all their acquaintances.

sp.speaker: Vintner
sp.p: I thank their worships all ▪ I am satisfied.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Say it again: do you hear gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Vintner
sp.p: I thank your worships all I am satisfied.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Why la, was not this better than hazarding our reputations upon trifles, and in such public as a tavern, such a questionable place.

sp.speaker: Tayl.
sp.p: True.

sp.speaker: Pur.
sp.p: Faith it was well thought on. Nay keep your way gentlemen: I have sworn master Bowcer, I will be last i'faith ▪ rascal the goblet.

sp.speaker: Fulk.
sp.p: Where sir?

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Peep yond sir under.

sp.speaker: Fulk.
sp.p: Here sir.

div.head: Actus. 4.

sp.speaker: Tayl.
sp.p: My husband is rode from home, make us delay , I know if your will be as free as your horse, you will see'●ee yet ere dinner: from Kingston this eleventh of November ▪ ha? these women are such creatures such importunate sweet souls: they'll scarse give a man leave to be ready, that's their only fault i'faith, if they be once set upon a thing, why there's no removing of 'em, till their pretty wills be fulfilled — oh pity thy poor oppressed client here sweet Cupid, that has scarce six hours vacation in a month, his causes hang in so many courts, yet never suffer my French adversary, nor his big swollen confederates to overthrow me, ▪ who without mercy would my blood carouse, and lay me in prison in a doctor's house:
Thy clemency great Cupid: peace, who comes here?

sp.speaker: Pursnet
sp.p: Sir gallant, well encountered.

sp.speaker: Talb.
sp.p: I both salute, and take my leave together.

sp.speaker: Purs.
sp.p: Why whether so fast sir ▪

lg.l: Excuse me pray, I'm in a little haste,
My horse waits for me.

sp.speaker: Purs.
sp.p: What some journey towards?

sp.speaker: Tayl.
sp.p: A light one i'faith sir.

lg.l: I am sorry that my business so commands me,
I cannot ride with you; but I make no question,
You have company enough.
Alas not any — nor do I desire it,
Why 'tis but to Kingston yonder.

sp.speaker: Purs.
sp.p: O cry you mercy sir,

sp.speaker: Tayl.
sp.p: Scape but one reach, there's little danger thither.

sp.speaker: Purs.
sp.p: True a little of Come-parke.

sp.speaker: Tayl.
sp.p: You've named the place sir, that's all I fear i'faith,

lg.l: Farewell sweet master Taylbee,
This fell out happily; I'll call this purchase mine, before I greet him,
E'en where his fear lies most, there will I meet him: boy.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Sir.

sp.speaker: Purs.
sp.p: Walk my horse behind yond thicket, give a word, if you descry.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: I have all perfect sir.

sp.speaker: Purs.
sp.p: So, he cannot now be long: what with my boy's dexterity at ordinaries, and my geldings celerity over hedge and ditch, but we make pretty shift to rub out, a gallant, for I have learned these principles.

lg.l: Stoop thou toth' world, 'twill on thy bosom tread,
It stoops to thee, if thou advance thy head:
The mind being far more excellent than fate,
'Tis fit our mind then be above our state;
Why should I write my catremitics in my brow,
To make them loathe me, that respect me now,
If every man were in his courses known;
Legs that now honour him, might spurn him down.
To conclude, nothing seems as it is but honesty, and that makes it so little regarded amongst us.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Eela, ha, ho.

sp.speaker: Pursnet
sp.p: The boy: he's hard at hand, I'll cross him suddenly: and here he comes; stand.

sp.speaker: Taylb.
sp.p: Ha!

sp.speaker: Purs.
sp.p: Deliver your purse sir.

sp.speaker: Tay.
sp.p: I feared none but this place i'faith, nay when my mind gives me a thing once.

lg.l: Quick, quick sir, quick.
I must dispatch three robberies yet ere night.

sp.speaker: Tayl.
sp.p: I'm glad you have such good doings by my troth sir.

sp.speaker: Purs.
sp.p: You'll fare never a whit the better for your flattery I warrant you sir.

sp.speaker: Tayl.
sp.p: I speak sincerely, 'tis pity such a proper-parted gentleman should want; nor shall you, as long as I have't about me, nay search and spare not: there's a purse in my left pocket as I take it, with fifteen pound in gold in't, and there's a fair chain of pearl in the other: nay I'll deal truly with you; it grieves me i'faith when I see such goodly men in distress, I'll rather want it myself than they should go without it.

sp.speaker: Purs.
sp.p: And that shows a good nature sir.

sp.speaker: Tayl.
sp.p: Nay though I say it, I have been always accounted a man of a good nature, I might have hanged myself ere this time else ▪ pray use me like a gentleman, take all, but injury not my body.

sp.speaker: Purs.
sp.p: You must pardon me sir, I must a little play the usurer, and bind you, for mine own security.

sp.speaker: Tayl.
sp.p: Alas there's no conscience in that sir, shall I enter into bond, and pay money too.

sp.speaker: Purs.
sp.p: Tut, I must not be betrayed.

sp.speaker: Tayl.
sp.p: Hear me but what I say sir, I do protest I would not be he that should betray a man, to be prince of the world.

sp.speaker: Purs.
sp.p: Mass that's the devil, I thank you heartily, for he's called prince ath' world.

sp.speaker: Tayl.
sp.p: You take me still at worst.

sp.speaker: Purs.
sp.p: Swear on this sword then, to set spurs to your horse, not to look back, to give no marks to any passenger.

sp.speaker: Tayl.
sp.p: Marks, why I think you have left me never a penny sir.

sp.speaker: Purs.
sp.p: I mean no marks of any.

sp.speaker: Tayl.
sp.p: I understand you sir.

sp.speaker: Purs.
sp.p: Swear then.

sp.speaker: Tayl.
sp.p: I'faith I do sir:

sp.speaker: Purs.
sp.p: Away.

sp.speaker: Tayl.
sp.p: I'm gone sir, by my troth of a fierce thief he seems to be a very honest gentleman.

sp.speaker: Purs.

lg.l: Why this was well adventured, trim a gallant:
Now with a courteous and long thusting eye,

sp.p: Let me behold my purchase, and try the soundues of my bones with laughter, how? is not this the chain of pearl I gave to that perjured harlot, 'tis, 'sfoot 'tis, the very chain, o damned mistress, ha; and this the purse, which not five days before I seen ▪ her filled with fair spur-royals — heart; the very gold? — 'slife is this no robbery, how many oaths flew towards heaven,

lg.l: Which ne'er came half way thither; but like fire drakes,
Mounted a little, gave a crack, and fell;
Feigned oaths bound up to sink more deep to hell.
What folded papers this? death — 'tis her hand.

sp.p: Master Taylbee, you know with what affection I love you, you do:
I count the world but as my prey to maintain you, the more dissembling quean you I must tell you,
I have sent you an embroidered purse here with fifty fair spur-royals in't — a pox on you for your labour wench: and I desire you of all loves to keep that chain of pearl from master Pursnets sight —
He cannot strumpet, I behold it now, unto thy secret torture:
So fare thee well, but be constant and want nothing.

As long as I have't i'faith? methinks it should have gone so, — well; what a horrible age do we live in, that a man cannot have a quean to himself let him but turn his back the best of her is chipped away like a court loaf, that when a man comes himself, has nothing but bombast; and these are 2. simple chippings here, does my boy pick, and I steal, to enrich myself, to keep her, to maintain him: why this is right the sequence of the world, — A. L. maintains her, she maintains a knight, he maintains a whore, she maintains a captain. So in like manner, the pocket keeps my boy, he keeps me, I keep her, she keeps him, it runs like quicksilver, from one to another; sfoot I perceive I have been the chief upholder of this gallant all this while; it appears true, we that pay dearest for our pasture are ever likely worse-used, 'sfoot he has a nag can run for nothing, has his choice, nay and gets by the running of him; — o fine world strange devils, and pretty damnable affections.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Lela ha, ho?

sp.speaker: Pursnet
sp.p: There boy, again, what news there?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Master, pist, master?

sp.speaker: Pursnet
sp.p: How now boy.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: I have descried a prize.

sp.speaker: Pursnet
sp.p: Another lad?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: The gull, the scholar?

sp.speaker: Pursnet
sp.p: Master Bowser:

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Ay, comes a long this way:

sp.speaker: Pursnet
sp.p: Without company.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: As sure, as he is your own.

lg.l: Back to thy place boy,
I have the luck today, to rob in safety:
Two precious cowards, whist: I hear him — stand

sp.speaker: Fits.
sp.p: You lie, I came forth to go.

sp.speaker: Pursnet
sp.p: Deliver your purse.

sp.speaker: Fits.
sp.p: 'Tis better in my pocket.

sp.speaker: Pursnet
sp.p: How now, at disputations, signior fool.

sp.speaker: Fits.
sp.p: I've so much logic to con●ute a knave, a thief, a rogue -

sp.speaker: Pursenet
sp.p: Hold, hold, sir, and you be a gentleman hold, let me rise.

lg.l: Heart 'tis the courtesy of his scarf unmasked him to me,
Above the lip by chance, I'll counterfeit,
Light, because I am a scholar, you think belike that scholars have no metal in 'em, but you shall find, — I have not done with you cousin.

sp.speaker: Pursnet
sp.p: As you're a gentleman:

sp.speaker: Fits.
sp.p: As you're a rogue?

sp.speaker: Pursnet
sp.p: Keep on upon your way sir:

sp.speaker: Fits.
sp.p: You bade me stand?

sp.speaker: Pursnet
sp.p: I have been once down for that:

sp.speaker: Fits.
sp.p: And then deliver?

sp.speaker: Pursnet
sp.p: Deliver me from you sir — o pax on't, has wounded me eela, ha, ho my horse, my horse boy:

lg.l: Have you your boy so ready: o thou world,
How art thou muffled in deceitful fonnes:
There's such a mist of these, and still hath been,
The brightness of true gentry is scarce seen:
This journey was most happily assigned,
I have found him dross both in his means and mind: what
Papers this he dropped? I'll look on't as I go.

sp.speaker: Pursnet
sp.p: A gull call you him, let me always set upon wise-men, they'll be afraid of their lives, they have a feeling of their iniquities, and knows what 'tis to die with fighting ▪ sfoot this gull lays on without fear, or wit, how deep's it sayst thou boy?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: By my faith three inches sir.

sp.speaker: Pursnet
sp.p: La, this was long of you, you rogue:

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Of me sir.

sp.speaker: Pursnet
sp.p: Forgive me dear boy, my wound ached, and I grew angry, there's hope of life boy, is there not?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Puh, my life for yours.

sp.speaker: Purs.
sp.p: A comfortable boy in man's extremes! I was ne'er so afraid in my life but the fool would have seen my face, he had me at such advantage, he might have commanded my Sca●f●, iscapt well there 'thad choked me; my reputation had been passed recovery, yet live I unsuspected, and still fit for gallants choice societies — but here I vow, if ere I see this Bowser when he cannot see me, either in by-lane, privilege place, court, alley, or come behind him when he's standing, or take him when he reels from a tavern late, pissing again a conduit, wall, or gate, when he's in such a plight and clear from me, I'll do that I am ashamed to speak till then.
Nay read forward, I have found 3. of your gallants, like your bewitching shame merely sophistical, there's your bawdgallant, your pocket-gallant, and your whore-gallant.
Master Taylbee.
That's he
I count the world but as my prey, to maintain you?
That's just the phrase and still of 'em all, to him: they meet altogether in one effect, and it may well hold too, for they all jump upon one cause, subands lechery.

lg.l: What shapes can flattery take, let me entreat you,
Both in the virgins right, and our good hopes
Since your hours are so fortunate, to proceed.

sp.p: Why he's base that fairs, until he crown his deed.

sp.speaker: Pursnet
sp.p: See that dissembling devil, that perjured strumpet.

sp.speaker: Curt.
sp.p: Welcome my soul's best wish, — o out alas ▪ thy arm bound in a scarf, I shall swoon instantly,

lg.l: Heart and I'll fetch you again in the same tune,
Oh my unmatched love, if any spark of life remain,
Look up, my comfort, my delight, my —

sp.speaker: 1. Cur.
sp.p: Oh good, oh good?

lg.l: The organ of her voice is tuned again,
There's hope in women, when their speech returns ▪
See like the moon after a black eclipse,
She by degrees recovers her pure light:
How cheers my love?
As one new waked out of a deadly trance,
The fit scarce quiet.

sp.speaker: Pursnet
sp.p: 'Twas terrible for the time, I'd much ado to fetch you.

lg.l: Shrew your fingers,
How came my comfort wounded, speak?

sp.speaker: Pursnet
sp.p: Faith in a fray last night.

lg.l: In a fray? will you lose your blood so vainly,
Many a poor creature lacks it, tell me how?
What was the quarrel?

sp.speaker: Pursnet
sp.p: Loath to tell you that.

sp.speaker: 1. Curt.
sp.p: Loath to tell me.

sp.speaker: Pursnet
sp.p: Yet 'twas my cause of coming.

sp.speaker: 1. Cur.
sp.p: Why then, must not I know it:

lg.l: Since you urge it, you shall,
You're a strumpet.

sp.speaker: 1. Curt.
sp.p: Oh news abroad sir?

sp.speaker: Pursnet
sp.p: Say you so.

sp.speaker: 1 Curt.
sp.p: Why you knew that the first night you lay with me.

sp.speaker: Pursnet
sp.p: Nay not to me, only but to the world.

sp.speaker: 1. Curt.
sp.p: Speak within compass man.

sp.speaker: Pursnet
sp.p: Faith you know none, you sail without.

sp.speaker: 1. Cur.
sp.p: I have the better skill then.

sp.speaker: Pursnet
sp.p: At my first step into a tavern-room, to spy that chain of pearl wound on a stranger's arm you begged of me.

sp.speaker: 1. Cur.
sp.p: How, you mistook it sure.

sp.speaker: Pursnet
sp.p: By heaven the very self same chain ▪

sp.speaker: 1. Curt.
sp.p: Oh cry you mercy, 'tis true, I'd forgotten it, 'tis s. George's day tomorrow, I lent it to my cousin only to grace his arm before his m●s●is.

sp.speaker: Pursnet
sp.p: Notable cunning.

sp.speaker: 1. Curt.
sp.p: And is this all now i'faith.

sp.speaker: Purs.
sp.p: Not, I durst go further.

sp.speaker: 1. Curt.
sp.p: Why, let me never possess your love, if you see not that again a Thursday morning, I take't unkindly i'faith you should fall out with me for such a trifle.

sp.speaker: Purs.
sp.p: Better and better.

sp.speaker: 1. Curt.
sp.p: Come, a kiss and friends.

sp.speaker: Purs.
sp.p: Away.

sp.speaker: 1. Curt.
sp.p: By this hand I'll spoil your atme and you will not.

sp.speaker: Purs.
sp.p: More for this then the devil.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Ye, at your book so hard.

lg.l: Against my will, are you there signior logic,
A pox of you sir.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Why how now, what has fate sent us here, in the name of Venus' goddess of cypress.

sp.speaker: Purs.
sp.p: A freebooter's pink sir, three or four inches deep.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: No more, that's conscionable i'faith.

sp.speaker: Taylb.
sp.p: Troth I'm sorry for't, pray how came it sir?

sp.speaker: Purs.
sp.p: Faith by a paltry fray, in Colman-streete.

sp.speaker: Fitsg.
sp.p: Coome-park he would say.

sp.speaker: Purs.
sp.p: No less than three at once sir, made a triangle with their swords and daggers, and all opposing me.

sp.speaker: Fits.
sp.p: And amongst those three, only one hurt you sir.

sp.speaker: Purs.
sp.p: Ex for ex.

sp.speaker: Tayl.
sp.p: Troth and I'll tell you what luck I had too, since I parted from you last.

sp.speaker: Purs.
sp.p: What I pray?

sp.speaker: Tayl.
sp.p: The day you offered to ride with me, I wish now I'd had your company, sfoot I was set upon in Coome-park by three too.

sp.speaker: Purs.
sp.p: Bah.

sp.speaker: Tayl.
sp.p: Robbed by this light of as much gold and jewels, as I valued at forty pound,

sp.speaker: Purs.
sp.p: Sure Saturn is in the fifth house.

sp.speaker: Tayl.
sp.p: I know not that, he may be in the sixth and he will for me, I am sure they were in my pocket wheresoever they were: but I'll ne'er refuse a gentleman's company again when 'tis offered me, I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: I must remember you, 'tis miter-night ladies.

sp.speaker: 2. Curt.
sp.p: Mass 'tis indeed, Friday today, I'd quite forgotten, when a woman's busy, how the time runs away.

sp.speaker: 1. Curt.
sp.p: O you've betrayed us both.

sp.speaker: Taylb.
sp.p: I understand you not.

sp.speaker: 1. Curt.
sp.p: You've let him see, the chain of pearl I gave you.

lg.l: Who him: will you believe me,
By this hand he never saw it.

sp.speaker: 1. Curt.
sp.p: Upon a stranger's arm he swore to me,

lg.l: Mass that may be, for the truth is i'faith,
I was robbed on't at Coome-park.

sp.speaker: 1. Curt.
sp.p: 'Twas that betrayed it,

lg.l: I would had stayed him,
He was no stranger, he was a thief i'faith,
For thieves will be no strangers.

sp.speaker: 1. Curt.
sp.p: How shall I excuse it?

sp.speaker: Bung.
sp.p: Nay I have you fast enough boy, you rogue.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Good sir, I beseech you sir, let me go.

sp.speaker: Bung ▪
sp.p: A pickpocket, nay you shall to Newgate luck you: is this your boy sir.

sp.speaker: Purs.
sp.p: How now boy? A monster? thy arm lined fast in another's pocket, where learned you that manners; what company have you kept o'late, that you are so transformed into a rogue, that shape I know not, believe me sir I much wonder at the alteration of this boy, where he should get this nature: as good a child to see to, and as virtuous, he has his creed by heart, reads me his chapter duly every night; he will not miss you one tittle in the nine commandments.

sp.speaker: Bungl.
sp.p: There's ten of 'em.

sp.speaker: Purs.
sp.p: I fear he skips o'er one; thou shalt not steal.

sp.speaker: Bung.
sp.p: Mass like enough.

sp.speaker: Purs.
sp.p: Else grace and memory, would quite abash the boy. Thou graceless imp, ah thou prodigious child, begotten at some aec ipse, degenerate rogue. Shame to thy friends, and to thy master eke: how far digressing from the noble mind of thy brave ancestors that lie in marble, with their coat a●●ors o'er 'em.

sp.speaker: Bung.
sp.p: Had he such friends?

sp.speaker: Pursnet
sp.p: The boy is well descended, though he be a rogue and has no feeling on't, yet for my sake, and for my reputations seek not the blood of the boy, his near allied to many men of worship now yet living, a fine old man to his father, it would kill his heart i'faith, heed away like a crysom.

sp.speaker: Bun.
sp.p: Alas good gentleman?

sp.speaker: Pursnet
sp.p: Ah shameless villain, complain'st thou? dost thou want?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: No, no, no, no.

sp.speaker: Purs.
sp.p: Art not well clad, thy hunger well resisted.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Yes, yes, yes, yes,

sp.speaker: Pursnet
sp.p: But thou shalt straight to Bridewell.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Sweet master.

sp.speaker: Pursnet
sp.p: Live upon bread and water, and chap choke.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: I beseech your worship.

sp.speaker: Bun.
sp.p: Come I'll be his surety for once:

sp.speaker: Pursnet
sp.p: You shall excuse me indeed sir?

sp.speaker: Bun.
sp.p: He will mend, 'a may prove an honest man for all this, I know gallant gentlemen now, that have done as much as this comes too in their youth.

sp.speaker: Pursnet
sp.p: Say you so sir?

sp.speaker: Bun.
sp.p: And as for Bridewell, that will but make him worse, 'a will learn more knavery there in one week, then will furnish him and his heirs for a hundreth year.

sp.speaker: Pursnet
sp.p: Deliver the boy.

sp.speaker: Bun.
sp.p: Nay I tell you true sir, there's none goes in there a quean, but she comes out an arrant whore I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Pursnet
sp.p: The boy comes not there for a million.

sp.speaker: Bun.
sp.p: No you had better forgive him by ten parts.

sp.speaker: Pursnet
sp.p: True, but a must not know it comes from me, down a your knees you rogue, and thank this gentleman has got your pardon.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: O I thank your worship:

sp.speaker: Pursnet
sp.p: A pox on you for a rogue, you put me to my set speech once a quarter:

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Nay gentlemen you quite forget your hour, ●ead master Bowser
sp.stage: Exeunt all but gold; and courtesan.

sp.speaker: 2. Cur.
sp.p: Let me go you're a dissembler

sp.speaker: Gold
sp.p: How.

sp.speaker: 2. Cur.
sp.p: Did not you promise me a new gown?

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Did I not? yes faith did I, and thou shalt have it, go sirrah run for a tailor presently.
Let me see for the colour now; orange tawny, peach colour, what sayst to a watchet satin?

sp.speaker: 2. Curt.
sp.p: Oh 'tis the only colour I affect.

sp.speaker: Tayler.
sp.p: A very orient colour, an't please your worships, I made a gown on't for a gentlewoman tother day, and it does passing well upon her.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: A watchet satin gown.

sp.speaker: Tayler.
sp.p: There your worship left sir.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Laid about tailor.

sp.speaker: Tayler.
sp.p: Very good sir.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: With four fair laces.

sp.speaker: Tayler.
sp.p: That will be costly sir.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: How you rogue costly, out ath'house, you slip-shod, sham-legged, brown-thread, penny-skeand rascal.

sp.speaker: 2. Curt.
sp.p: Nay my sweet love.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Hang him rogue, he's but a butcher neither, come I'll send thee a fellow worth a hundred of this, if the slave were clean enough.

div.stage: In the midst of the music enter one bringing in a suit of satin, knocks at Taylbee's door, enter his man.

sp.p: Who knocks.
A christian: pray is not this master Taylbee's lodging, I was directed hither .
Yes, this is my master's lodging.
Cry you mercy sir. Is he yet stirring.
He's awake, but not yet stirring, for he played away half his clothes last night
My mistress commends her secrets unto him, and presents him by me with a new satin suit here.
Mass that comes happily.
And she hopes the fashion will content him.
There's no doubt to be had of that sir — your mistress name I pray? you're much preciously welcome.
I thank you uncommonly sir.
The suit shall be accepted I warrant you sir.
That's all my mistress desires sir.
Fare you well sir.
Fare you well sir.
This will make my master leap out of the bed for joy, and dance Wigmois galliard in his shift about the chamber?

div.stage: The music plays on a while, then enter; Taylbee his man after trussing him.

sp.speaker: Taylb.
sp.p: Came this suit from mistress Cleveland?

sp.speaker: Jack.
sp.p: She sent it secretly sir.

sp.speaker: Taylb
sp.p: A pretty requiteful squall, I like that woman, that can remember a good turn 3 months a'er the date, it shows both a good memory, and a very feeling spirit.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.p: This came fortunately sir, after all your ill luck last night.

sp.speaker: Taylb.
sp.p: I'd beastly casting Jack.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.p: O abominable sir, you had the scurviest hand — the old servingman swooped up all;

sp.speaker: Taylb.
sp.p: I am glad the fortune lighted upon the poor fellow by my troth, 'tmade his master mad?

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.p: Did you mark that sir, ● warrant he has the doggedst master of any poor fellow under the dog-sign, I'd rather serve your worship, I'll say that behind your back sir, for nothing, as indeed I have no standing wages at all, your worship knows.

sp.speaker: Taylb.
sp.p: O but your vails Jack your vails considered, when you run to and fro between me and mistresses.

sp.speaker: Ia
sp.p: I must confess my vails are able to keep an honest man go I where I lift.

sp.speaker: Taylb.
sp.p: Go to then Jack.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.p: But those vails stand with the state of your body sir as long as you hold up your head, if that droop once, farewell you, farewell I, farewell all, and droop it will, though all the caudles in Europe should put to their helping hands to't; 'tis e'en as uncertain as playing now vu now down, for if the bill rise to above thirty, here's no place for players, so if your years rise to above 〈…〉 ty, there's no room for old lechers.

sp.speaker: Tabl.
sp.p: And that's the reason on all rooms are taken up for young temp'ers?

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.p: You're in the right sir?

sp.speaker: Tal●.
sp.p: Pize on't I pawned a good beaver hat to master Frip last night Jack,
I feel the want of it now, — hark who's that knocks;
Is master Taylbee stirring?

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.p: What's your pleasure with him, he walks here ith' hall.
Give your worship good morrow,

sp.speaker: Taylb.
sp.p: Welcome honest lad;
A letter from my mistress.

sp.speaker: Taylb.
sp.p: Who's the mistress?
Mistress 〈…〉 block.

sp.speaker: Taylb.
sp.p: Mistress New-blocke my sincere love how does she?
Faith only ●●n the wait of your sight.

sp.speaker: Taylb.
sp.p: A●asse ●eere sweet, I've had such business, I protest I ne'er stood still since I saw her.
She has sent your worship a beaver hat here, with a band best in fashion.

sp.speaker: Taylb.
sp.p: How shall I requite this dear soul?
'Tis not a thing fit for me to tell you sir, for I have three years to serve yet: your worship knows how I warrant you;

sp.speaker: Tal●.
sp.p: I know the drift of her letter, and for the beaver, say, I accept it highly.
O she will be a proud woman of that sir.

sp.speaker: Tayl.
sp.p: And hark thee tell thy mistress as I'm a gentleman, I'll dispatch her out of hand, the first thing I do a my credit, canst thou remember these words now?
Yes sirrah you are a gentleman you'll dispatch her out of hand the first thing you do

sp.speaker: Tayl.
sp.p: Ia my credit.
O of your credit, I thought not of that fir.

sp.speaker: Taylb.
sp.p: Remember that good boy?
Fear it not now fir.

sp.speaker: Tayl
sp.p: I dreamt to nigh Jack, I should have a secret supply out a'th city

sp.speaker: Ia.
sp.p: Your dream crawls out partly well sir, — what news there now?
I have an arrant no master Taylbee —

sp.speaker: Jack.
sp.p: Yonder walks my master;

Mistress Tiffany commends her to your worship and has sent you your ten pound in gold back gain, and says she cannot furnish you of the same lawn you desire, till after
all Hollantide —

sp.speaker: Tayl.
