sp.p: Thank her she would let me understand so much? ha, ha, — this wench will live, why this was sent like a work woman now, the rest are borchers to her, faith I commend her cunning, she's a fool, that makes her servant fellow to her heart, it robs her of respect, dams up all duty, keeps her in awe e'en of the slave she keeps.

lg.l: This takes a wise course I commend her more,
Sends back the gold, I never saw before:
Well women are my best friends i'faith,
Takes lands give me good legs:
Firm back white hand black eye, brown hair,
And add but to these five a comely stature,
Let others live by art and I by nature.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.p: Master Bowser master Bowser, ha, ha, ho, master Bowser.

sp.speaker: Fusg
sp.p: Holla:

sp.speaker: Gol.
sp.p: What not out of thy kennel, master Bowser.

sp.speaker: Fitsg.
sp.p: Master Goldstone, your an early gallant sir?

sp.speaker: Gol.
sp.p: A fair cloak yonder i'faith, — by my troth a bed master Bowser, you remember your promise well o'er night.

sp.speaker: Fitsg.
sp.p: Why what's o'clock sir?

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.p: Do you ask that now, why the chimes are spent at saint brides.

sp.speaker: Fitsg.
sp.p: 'Tis a gentleman's hour, saith master Goldstone I'll be ready in a trice.

sp.speaker: Gol.
sp.p: Away there's no trust to you:

sp.speaker: Fits.
sp.p: Faith I'll come instantly?

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Nay choose whether you will or no, by my troth your cloak shall go before you —

sp.speaker: Fits.
sp.p: Nay master Goldstone I ha' sworn — do you hear sir:

sp.speaker: Gol.
sp.p: Away, away, faith I'm angry with you, pox, a bed now I'm ashamed of it.

sp.speaker: Fits.
sp.p:
Foot my cloak, my cloak master Goldstone, 'slife what meant you by this sir you'll bring it back again, I hope, no not yet, by my troth I care very little for such kind of jesting, methinks this familiarity now extends a little too far, unless it be a new fashion come forth this morning ▪ secretly yesterday 'twould have shown unmannerly, and saucily; I scarce
know yet what to think on't, well there's no great profit in standing in my shirt, I'll on with my clothes, has bound me to follow the suit, my cloaks a stranger he was made but yesterday, and I do not love to trust him alone in company.

sp.speaker: Frip.
sp.p: What may I conjecture of this Goldstone? he has not only pawned to me this cloak, but the very diamond and saphire, which I bestowed upon my new love at master Primero's house; the cloaks new and comes fitly, to do me great grace at a wedding this morning, to which I was solemnly invited. I can continue change more than the proudest gallant of 'em all; yet never bestow penny of myself, my pawns do so kindly furnish me: but the sight of these jewels is able to cloy me, di● I nor preserve my stomach the better for the wedding dinner, a gift could never have come in a more patient hour, nor to be better digested; is she proved false, — but I'll not fiet today no ▪ chafe my blood.

sp.speaker: Pursnet
sp.p: Ha, yonder goes Bowser, the place is fit: — boy stand with my horse at corner, I owe you for a pink 3. inches deep sir?

sp.speaker: Frip.
sp.p: On — oh — oh;

sp.speaker: Pursnet
sp.p: Take that in part of payment; for Coome-park:

sp.speaker: Frip.
sp.p: On — oh — oh?

sp.speaker: Fitsg.
sp.p: How now, who's this? sfoot one of our gallants, knocked down like a calf, is there such a plague of 'em here at London, they begun to knock 'em ath' head already:

sp.speaker: Frip.
sp.p: O master Bowser, pray rend me your hand sir; I am slain:

lg.l: Slain and alive? o cruel execution?
What man so savage-spirited durst presume,
To strike down satin on two taffeties cut:
Or lift his hand against a bevet hat.
Some rogue that owes me money, and had no other means
To a wedding dinner: I must be d'est myself methinks .

sp.speaker: Fit'g.
sp.p: How why this my cloak, life how came my cloak hither?

sp.speaker: Pur.
sp.p: Well-said master Bowcer, first the device, a fair purse wide open, the mouth downward, the word alienis ecce crumenis?

sp.speaker: Pursnet
sp.p: What's that prithee?

sp.speaker: Fits.
sp.p: Your bounty powers itself forth to all men.

sp.speaker: Purs.
sp.p: And so it does i'faith? that's all my fault, bountiful?

sp.speaker: Fits.
sp.p: Master Goldstone here's yours sir, 3. silver dice, the word, fratremque patremque?

sp.speaker: Gol.
sp.p: And what's that?

sp.speaker: Fits.
sp.p: Fortune of my side?

sp.speaker: Gol.
sp.p: Well-said little Bowcer i'faith?

sp.speaker: Tayl.
sp.p: What say you to me sir?

sp.speaker: Fits.
sp.p: For the device a candle in a corner; the word, consumptio, victus:

sp.speaker: Tayl.
sp.p: The meaning of that sir?

sp.speaker: Fits.
sp.p: My light is yet in darkness, till ●in●oy her, right sir?

sp.speaker: Pri
sp.p: Now mine sir?

sp.speaker: Fits.
sp.p: The device an unvalued pearl hid in a cave.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.p: Ah ha sirs?

sp.speaker: Fits.
sp.p: The word, occultes vendit honores;

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.p: Very-good I warrant,

sp.speaker: Fits.
sp.p: A black man's a pearl in a fair lady's eye,

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.p: I said 'twas some such thing;

sp.speaker: Frip.
sp.p: My turn must needs come now; am I fitted master Bowcer?

sp.speaker: Fits.
sp.p: Trust to me, your device here is a cuckoo sitting on a tree,

sp.speaker: Frip.
sp.p: The Welsh leaguer, good.

sp.speaker: Fits.
sp.p: The word, en anis ex a●ib●s.

sp.speaker: Frip.
sp.p: I marry sir.

sp.speaker: Fits.
sp.p: Why do you know what 'tis sir.

sp.speaker: Frip.
sp.p: No by my troth not yet sir ▪

sp.speaker: Fits.
sp.p: O, I keep one tune, I recant not.

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.p: I me like the cuckoo in that indeed, where I love I hold.

sp.speaker: Fits.
sp.p: Did I not promise you I would fit you.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: They re all very well done i'faith, and very scholarlike, though I say't before thy face little Bowcer, but I would not have thee proud on't now: come if this be performed well.

sp.speaker: Pur.
sp.p: Who the boy, he has performed deeper matters then this.

sp.speaker: Pyam.
sp.p: I a pox on him, I think was in my pocket now, and truth were known.

sp.speaker: Bungl.
sp.p: I caught him once in mine.

sp.speaker: Fits.
sp.p: Suppose the shields are presented, than you begin boy.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: I representing Mercury, am a pickpocket, and have his part at my finger's ends, page I am to that great and secret thief, magno illo et Secret● latroni.

sp.speaker: Bungl.
sp.p: There you make your honour sir ▪

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: At latroni.

sp.speaker: Purs.
sp.p: You have it sir.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Latroni, that's mine.

sp.speaker: Fits.
sp.p: He confesses the thief's his.

sp.speaker: Purs.
sp.p: Remember boy, you point latroni to me.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: To you master, proceed ▪

sp.speaker: Ftis.
sp.p: These four are his companions, the one a notable cheater, that will cozen his own father.

sp.speaker: Bou.
sp.p: Master Goldstone.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Let me alone master Boucer, I can take mine own turn.

sp.speaker: Bou.
sp.p: Why.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Peace.

sp.speaker: Fits.
sp.p: The second an notorious lecher maintained by harlots cuius virtus consumptio corpus.

sp.speaker: Tayl.
sp.p: That's I master Bowcer.

sp.speaker: Bou.
sp.p: There you remember your honour sir.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Ille leno pretiosissi●●s, virgineos ob lucrum vendens honores.

sp.speaker: Purs.
sp.p: It sounds very well i'faith.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Postremus ill●, quamuis apparatus splendidus, is no otherwise but a broker, these feathers are not his own, sed anis ex auibus; all which to be nothing but truth, will appear by the event.

sp.speaker: Fits.
sp.p: I'faith here's all now gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Short and pithy.

sp.speaker: Tayl.
sp.p: A good boy i'faith and a pregnant.

sp.speaker: Purs.
sp.p: I dare put trust in the boy sir; forget not sirrah at any ▪ hand to point that same latroni to me.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: I warrant you master.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Come gentlemen the time beckons us away.

sp.speaker: Fits.
sp.p: Ay, furnish gentlemen, furnish.

sp.speaker: Purs.
sp.p: Hark one word master Boucer, what's the same latroni, I have a good mind to that word i'faith.

sp.speaker: Frip.
sp.p: Is it yours sir,? Master Goldstone pawned it to me this morning fresh and ●a●●ing ▪ and borrowed five pound upon't.

sp.speaker: Fits.
sp.p: How, pawned it? pray let me near out this story, come, and I'll lend you to the next barber-surgeons; — pawned my cloak?

sp.speaker: Bung.
sp.p: How now Mar●aduke what's the wager;

sp.speaker: Marm.
sp.p: Nay my care is at end sir, now I am come to the sight of you? my mistress your cousin entreats you to take part of a dinner with her at home at her house, and bring what gentleman you please to accompany you.

sp.speaker: Bun.
sp.p: Thank my sweet coz, I'll munch with her say.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: I'll tell her so.

sp.speaker: Bun.
sp.p: Marmaduke —

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Sir?

sp.speaker: Bun.
sp.p: Will there be any stockfish thinkst thou?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: How sir?

sp.speaker: Bun.
sp.p: Tell my coz I've a great appetite to stockfish i'faith — master Goldstone I'll entreat you to be the gentleman that shall accompany me.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: No●? me sir?

sp.speaker: Bung.
sp.p: You sir.

sp.speaker: Bung
sp.p: By my troth concluded, what state bears thy coz sirrah?

sp.speaker: Bung.
sp.p: O a fine merchant's wife, —

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.p: Or rather a merchant's fine wife —

sp.speaker: Bung.
sp.p: Trust me and that's the properer phrase here at London, and 'tis as absurd too, to call him ●ine merchant, for being at sea, a man knows not what pickle he is in.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.p: Why true —

sp.speaker: Bung.
sp.p: Yet my coz will be served in plate I can tell you, she has her silver lug● and her guilt tankards.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.p: Fie.

sp.speaker: Bun.
sp.p: Nay you shall see a house dressed up i'faith, you must not think to tread ath' ground when you come there. —

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.p: No, how there?

sp.speaker: Bun.
sp.p: Why upon paths made of fig-frailes, and white blankets cut out in steaks.

sp.speaker: Go
sp.p: Away — I have thought of a device, where shall we meet an hour hence.

sp.speaker: Bung.
sp.p: In Paul's.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.p: Agreed.

lg.l: The broker-gallant, and the cheating-gallant,
Now I have found 'em all, I so rejoice,
That the redeeming of my cloak I weigh not:
I have spied him.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Pax here's Boucer.

sp.speaker: Fits
sp.p: Master Goldstone, my cloak, come where's my cloak sir?

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: O you're a sure gentleman; especially if a man stand in need of you, he may be slain in a morning to breakfast, ere you vouchsafe to peep out of your lodging.

sp.speaker: Fits.
sp.p: How?

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: No less than four gallants, as I'm a gentleman, drew all upon me at once, and opposed me so spitefully, that I not only lost your cloak ith' fray.

sp.speaker: Fitsg.
sp.p: C●mes it in there?

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: But my ticle hangers, sirrah, I think thou hast seen e●●.

sp.speaker: Fitsg.
sp.p: Never i●a●h sir.

sp.speaker: Gold
sp.p: Those with the two unicorns, all wrought in pearl and gold pex on't it frets me ten times more than the loss of the platty cloak; prithee and thou lovest me speak no more on●t, it brings the unicorns into my mind, and thou wouldst not think how the conceit grieves me: I will not do thee that disgrace i'faith, to offer thee any satisfaction, for in my soul I think thou scornest it thou bearest that mind in my conscience ▪ I have always said so of thee; fare thee well, when shall I see thee at my chamber, when?

sp.speaker: Fitsg.
sp.p: Every day shortly.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: I have fine toys to show thee.

sp.speaker: Fits.
sp.p: You win my heart then:

The devil scarce knew what a portion he gave his children, when he allowed 'em large impudence to live upon, and so turned 'em into th'world, surely he gave away the third part of the riches of his kingdom, revenues are but fools to't; the filed tongue and the undaunted forehead,

lg.l: Are mighty patrimonies, wealthier than those
The city-sire, or the court-father leaves,
in these behold it, riches oft like slaves
Revolt, they bear their foreheads to their graves,
What soonest grasps advancement, me ● great suits
Trips down rich widows, gains repute and name,
Makes way where ere it comes, bewitches all
Thou impudence, the minion of our days
On whose pale cheeks favour and fortune plays!
Call you these your five gallants, trust me they're rare fellows
They live on nothing; many cannot live on something,
Here they may take example; — suspectless virgin!
How easy had thy goodness been beguiled
Now only rests, that as to me they're known,
So to the world their base arts may be shown.

sp.speaker: Pursnet
sp.p: Art sure thou sawest him receive't boy?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Forty pound in gold as I'm a gentleman born,

sp.speaker: Pursnet
sp.p: Thy father gave the ramshead boy?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: No you're deceived my mother gave that sir.

sp.speaker: Pursnet
sp.p: What's thy mothers, is thy fathers;

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: I'm sorry it holds in the ramshead, see here he walks, I was sure he came into Paul's, the gold had been yours master long ere this, but that he wears both his hands in his pockets:

sp.speaker: Pursnet
sp.p: How unfortunately is my purpose seated, what the devil should come in his mind to keep in his hands so long, the biting but of a paltry louse would do me great kindness now, I knew not how to requite it, will no rascal creature assist me, stay, what i● I did impudently salute 'em out, good, boy be ready boy.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Upon the least advantage sir?

sp.speaker: Pursnet
sp.p: You're most devoutly met in Paul's sir?

sp.speaker: Pia.
sp.p: So are you, but I scarce remember you sir.

sp.speaker: Pursnet
sp.p: O I cry you mercy sir, I pray pardon me I fear I have tendered an offence sir, troth I took you at the first for one master Dumplin a Norfolk gentleman.

sp.speaker: Pia.
sp.p: There's no harm done yet sir?

sp.speaker: Pursnet
sp.p: I hope he is there by this time, how now boy, hast it?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: No by troth have I not, this labours lost, 'tis in the right pocket, and he kept that hand in sure enough.

sp.speaker: Purs.
sp.p: Unpractised gallant, salute me but with one hand, like a counterfeit soldier, oh times and manners? are we grown beasts, do we salute by halves, are not our limbs at leisure, where's comely nurture, the Italian kiss, or the French cringe, with the Polonian waste: are all forgotten, than misery follows — surely fate forbade it, had he employed but his right hand, I'd had it: — it must be an everlasting device I think, that procures both his hands out at once: do you walk sir.

sp.speaker: Bung.
sp.p: No I stay a little for a gentleman's coming too.

sp.speaker: Piam.
sp.p: Farewell then sir, I have forty pound in gold about me, which I must presently send down into the country.

sp.speaker: Bung.
sp.p: Fare you well sir: I wonder master Goldstone spares my company so long, 'tis now about the navel of the day, upon the belly of noon.

div.stage: Enter Goldst. and his man disguised both.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: See where he walks, be sure you let off at a twinkling now.

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.p: When did I miss you, — your worship has forgotten, you promised mistress Newcut your cousin, to dine with her this day.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Mass that was well remembered.

sp.speaker: Bung.
sp.p: I am bold to salute you sir.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Sir.

sp.speaker: Bung.
sp.p: Is mistress Newcut your cousin sir.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Yes, she's a cousin of mine sir.

sp.speaker: Bung.
sp.p: Then I am a cousin of yours, by the sister's side.

sp.speaker: Gold
sp.p: Let me salute you then, I shall be glad of your farther acquaintance.

sp.speaker: Bung.
sp.p: I am a bidden guest here too.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Indeed sir?

sp.speaker: Bung.
sp.p: Faith invited this morning.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Your good company, shall be kindly embraced sir.

sp.speaker: Bung.
sp.p: I walk a turn or two here for a gentleman, but I think he'll either overtake me, or be before me.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: 'Tis very likely sir; there sirrah, go to dinner, and about two wait for me?

sp.speaker: Bung.
sp.p: Nay let him come between two and three cozen, for we love to sit long at dinner ith' city.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Come sweet cousin.

lg.l: Nay cozen, keep your way cozen,
Good cousin I will not i'faith cozen.

sp.speaker: New,
sp.p: Why how now sirrah, upon twelve of the clock, and not the cloth laid yet — must we needs keep exchange time still.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: I am about it forsooth.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: You're about it forsooth; you're still about many things, but you ne'er do one well, I am an ass to keep thee in th' 'House now my husbands at sea, thou hast no audacity with thee, a foolish dreaming lad, fitter to be in the garret, than in any place else, no grace, nor manly behaviour; when didst thou ever come to me, but with thy head hanging down, o decheerefull prentice, uncomfortable servant: pray heaven the gull my cousin has so much wit left, as to bring master Taylbee along with him; my comfort, my delight, for that was the chiefest cause I did invite him, I bade him bring what gentlemen he pleased to accompany him, as far as I durst go, why may he not then make choice of master Taylbee, had he my wit or feeling he would do't.

sp.speaker: Bun.
sp.p: Where's my sweet cousin here, dos she lack any guess?

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: Ever such guess as you, you're welcome cozen.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: I am rude lady.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: You're most welcome sir.

lg.l: There will be a gallant here anon coz,
He promised faithfully.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: Who is't master Taylbee?

sp.speaker: Bung.
sp.p: Master Taylbee, no master Goldstone.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: Mayst Goldstone; I could think well of that Goldstone, wert not for one vild trick he has.

sp.speaker: Gol.
sp.p: What's that lady?

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: In jest, he will pawn his punc es for suppers.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: That's a vild part in him i'faith, and he were my brother.

sp.speaker: New
sp.p: Pray gentlemen sit a while, your dinner shall come presently.

lg.l: Ye mistress Newcut, at first give me a trip,
A close bite always asks a secret nip.

sp.speaker: Bun.
sp.p: My cousin here is a very kind natured soul i'faith, in her humour.

sp.speaker: Gol.
sp.p: Puh you know her not so well as I coz, I have observed her in all her humours you ne'er saw her a little waspish I think.

sp.speaker: Bung.
sp.p: I have i'faith.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.p: Puh, then yea never saw pretty humour in your life, I can bring her into't when I list.

sp.speaker: Bun.
sp.p: Would you could i'faith.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.p: Would I could? by my troth and I were sure thou couldst keep thy countenance coz, what a pretty jest have I thought upon already to entertain time before dinner.

sp.speaker: Bun.
sp.p: Preach coz what is't, I love a jest a life i'faith.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.p: Ah but I am jealous you will not keep your countenance i'faith.

sp.speaker: Bun.
sp.p: Why yea shall see a pretty story of a humour.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.p: Faith I'll try you for once, you know my cousin will wonder when she comes in to see the cloth laid and never a salt upon the board.

sp.speaker: Bu.
sp.p: That's true i'faith.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.p: Now will I stand a while out of sight with it, and give her humour play a little.

sp.speaker: Bung.
sp.p: Coz dost thou love me, and thou wilt ever do any thing for me, do't.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.p: Marry I build upon you countenance.

sp.speaker: Bung.
sp.p: Why dost thou think I'm an ass coz?

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.p: I would be loath to undertake it else, for if you should burst out presently, coz the jest would be spoilt.

sp.speaker: Bung.
sp.p: Why do not I know that, away, stand close, so, so mum cozen? A merry companion i'faith, here will be good sport anon, — whist she comes?

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: I make you stray long for a bad dinner, here cozen, if master Goldstone were come, the meats e'en ready.

sp.speaker: Bu.
sp.p: Some great business detains him cousin, but he'll not be long now?

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: Why how now, cuds my life, —

sp.speaker: Bun.
sp.p: Why?

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: Was ever mistress so plagued with a shetle-headed servant — why Marmaduke.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: I come forsooth:

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: Able to shame me from generation to generation.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Did you call forsooth?

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: Come hither forsooth — did you lay this cloth?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Yes forsooth:

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: Do you use to lay a cloth without a salt, a salt, a salt, a salt, a salt, a salt.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: How many salts would you have, I'm sure I set the best ith' house upon the boor.

sp.speaker: Bu.
sp.p: How? cozen: — sings — cozen, cozen, did call coz.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: Did you see a salt upon the board when you came in.

sp.speaker: Bung.
sp.p: Puh.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: Come, come, I thought as much, beshrew your singers, where is't now?

sp.speaker: Bun.
sp.p: Your cousin yonder.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: Why the man's mad.

sp.speaker: Bun.
sp.p: Cousin, hist cozen.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: What say you.

sp.speaker: Bun.
sp.p: Puh, I call not you, I call my cousin, come forth with th' salt cozen: ha, how, nobody: why was not he that came in e'en now your cousin?

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: My cousin: oh my bell salt, oh my great bell salt.

sp.speaker: Bung.
sp.p: The tenor bell salt; o here comes master Goldstone now cozen, he may tell us some news on him. Did you not meet a fellow about door, with a great silver salt under his arm.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: No sure, I met none such.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: Pardon me sir, I forgotten all this while to bid you welcome. I shall loathe this room for ever. Take hence the cloth you unlucky maple-faced rascal, come you shall dine in my chamber sir.

sp.speaker: Gol.
sp.p: No better place lady.

sp.speaker: Pya.
sp.p: No less than forty pound in fair gold at one lift, the next shall swoon, and sown again till the devil fetch him ere I set hand to him, heart, nothing vexes me so much ▪ but that I paid the goldsmith for the change too not an hour before, had I let it alone in the chain of silver as it was at first, it might have given me some notice at his departure, sfoot I could fight with a windmill now, sure 'twas some unlucky villain, why should he come and salute me wrongfully too mistake me at noon day, now I think on't in cold blood? it could not be but an induction to some villainous purpose, well, I shall meet him —

sp.speaker: Pursnet
sp.p: This forty pound came fortunately to redeem my chain of pearl from mortgage, I would not care how often I swooned to have such a good caudle to comfort me, gold and pearl is very restorative. —

sp.speaker: Pyam.
sp.p: See yonder's the rogue I suspect for foul play, I'll walk muffled by him, offer some offence or cause of a quarrel, only to try his temper, if he be a coward, he's the likelier to be a rogue, an infallible note.

sp.speaker: Purs.
sp.p: What a pox ail you sir, would I had been aware of you.

sp.speaker: Pyam.
sp.p: Sir, speak you to me?

sp.speaker: Pursnet
sp.p: Not I sir, pray keep on your way I have nothing to say to you.

sp.speaker: Pyam.
sp.p: You're a rascal.

sp.speaker: Pursnet
sp.p: You may, say your pleasure sir, — but I hope I go not like a rascal.

sp.speaker: Pyam.
sp.p: Are you ▪ fain to fly to your clothes, because ya●e gallant, why there's no rascal, like your calla●t rascal believe that.

sp.speaker: Pursnet
sp.p: You have taken me at such an hour, faith you may call me e'en what you please, nothing will move me.

sp.speaker: Pyam.
sp.p: No, I'll make somewhat n ooue you? draw? I suspected you were a rogue, and you have pursed it up well with a coward?

sp.speaker: Purs.
sp.p: Who my patron.

sp.speaker: Pyam.
sp.p: Keep out you rascal.

lg.l: The gest that did me the kindness in Paul's,
Hold as you are a gentleman, you'll give me breath sir.

sp.speaker: Pyam.
sp.p: Are you there with me, a vengeance stop you, you have found breath enough to run away from me I will never meet this slave hereafter in a morning but I will breathe myself upon him, since I can have no other satisfaction, he shall save me that forty pound in fence-school.

sp.speaker: Gold.

lg.l: When things are cleanly carried, sign of judgement,
I was the welcom'st gallant to her alive,
After the salt was stolen; then a good dinner,
A fine provoking meal which drew on apace,
The pleasure of a day-bed, and I had it:
This here one ring can witness, when I parted,
Who but seewte master Goldstone, I left her in that trance.
What cannot wit so it be impudent
Device and compass? I would fain know that fellow now,
That would suspect me but for what I am.

sp.p: He lives not,; 'tis all in the conveyance, what? Thou lookest not like a beggar, what mak'st thou on the ground, I have a hand to help thee up, a fair chain of pearl, surely a merchant's wife gives lucky bandsell; they that find pearl may wear't at a cheap rate, marry my lady dropped it from her arm for a device to toll me to her bed, I've seen as great a matter — who be these? I'll be too crafty for you, o monsieur primero, signior Fr●, is it you gallants.

sp.speaker: Frip
sp.p: Sweet master Goldstone?

sp.speaker: Tayl.
sp.p: Every bawd exceeds me in fortune: master Primero was robbed of a carcanet upon Monday last ▪ laid the goldsmiths and found it. I ha' laid goldsmits jeweller, burnisher broker, and the devil and all I think, yet could never so much as here of that chain of pearl, he was a notable thief, he works close; peace, who be these, ha me see, by this light there it 'tis back lest they see thee; a happy minute, Goldstone what an age do we breathe in, who, that saw him now would think he were maintained by purses: so, who, that meets me, would think I were maintained by wenches, as far as I can see 'tis all one case, and holds both in one court, we are both maintained by the common road way? Keep thou thine own heart, thou liv'st unsuspected, I lose you again now.

lg.l: But I pray you tell me,
Met you no gentlewomen by the way you came?

sp.speaker: Frip.
sp.p: Not any what should they be?

lg.l: Nay I do but ask,
Because a gentlewoman's glove was found,
Near to the place I met you?

sp.speaker: Primero.
sp.p: Faith we saw none sir.

sp.speaker: Taylb.
sp.p: Good officers, upon suspicion of felony.

sp.speaker: Cunst.
sp.p: Very good sir
What call you the thieves name you do suspect?

sp.speaker: Tayl.
sp.p: Master Justinian Goldstone.

sp.speaker: I.
sp.p: Remember, master justice Goldstone, a terrible world the whilst, my masters.

sp.speaker: Tayl.
sp.p: Look you that's he; upon him officers.

sp.speaker: I.
sp.p: I see him not yet, which is he sir.

sp.speaker: Tayl.
sp.p: Why that.

sp.speaker: I.
sp.p: He a thief sir, who that gentleman ith' Satt in?

sp.speaker: Tayl.
sp.p: E'en he.

sp.speaker: I.
sp.p: Farewell sir, you're a merry gentleman.

sp.speaker: Tayl.
sp.p: As you will answer it officers, I'll bear you out, I'll be your warrant.

sp.speaker: I.
sp.p: Nay and you say so, what's his name then.

sp.speaker: Tayl.
sp.p: Justinian Goldstone.

sp.speaker: I.
sp.p: Master Justinian Goldstone, we apprehend you sir upon suspicion of felony.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Me.

sp.speaker: Tayl.
sp.p: You sir.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.p: I charge you in the King's name gentlemen to assist us.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Master Taylbee?

sp.speaker: Tayl.
sp.p: The same man sir.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Life what's the news?

sp.speaker: Tayl.
sp.p: Ha you forgotten Come-parke?

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Come-parke? no, 'tis in Kingston way.

sp.speaker: Tayl.
sp.p: I believe you'll find it so.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: I not deny it.

sp.speaker: I.
sp.p: Bear witness has confessed.

sp.speaker: Gol.
sp.p: What have I confessed, pair of coxcombs indubitable?

lg.l: I was robbed finely of this chain of pearl there,
And forty fair spur-royals.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Did I rob you?

sp.speaker: Tayl.
sp.p: There where I find my goods I may suspect sir.

sp.speaker: Frip.
sp.p: I dreamt this would be his end.

lg.l: See how I am wronged gentlemen:
As I have a soul, I found this chain of pearl,
Not three yards from this place, just when I met you.

sp.speaker: Tayl.
sp.p: Ha, ha!

sp.speaker: Frip.
sp.p: Yet the law's such, if he but swear 'tis you, you're gone.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Pox on't, that ere I saw't.

sp.speaker: Frip.
sp.p: Can you but swear 'tis he, do but that, and you tickle him i'faith?

sp.speaker: Taylb.
sp.p: Nay and it come once to swearing let me alone:

sp.speaker: Frip
sp.p: Say and hold, he called my jewels counterfeit, and so cheated the poor wench of 'em:

sp.speaker: I.
sp.p: Come bring him away, come?

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: 'Twill call my state in question!

sp.speaker: Purs.
sp.p: I think what's got by theft doth never prosper, now lost my chain of pearl — come master Goldstone, let's go this mine i'faith,

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: The chain of pearl?

sp.speaker: Pur.
sp.p: By my trothit's mine;

sp.speaker: Gold
sp.p: By my troth much good do't you sir?

sp.speaker: Frip.
sp.p: I'm glad in my soul fie — gnaws,

sp.speaker: Cunst.
sp.p: Deliver your weapons,

sp.speaker: Pursnet
sp.p: How?

sp.speaker: Cunst.
sp.p: You're apprehended upon suspicion of felony?

sp.speaker: Pursnet
sp.p: Felony? what's that '

sp.speaker: Taylb.
sp.p: Was it you i'faith, sir all this while, that did me that kindness to ease both my pockets at Coom-park:

sp.speaker: Pursnet
sp.p: I sir? pray gentlemen draw near, let's talk among ourselves, stand a part scoundrel; — must every gentleman be up braided in public that flies out now and then upon necessity, to be themes for pedlars and weavers? this should not be, 'twas never seen among the Romans; nor read we of it in the time of Brute ▪ are we more brutish now? did I list to blab, do not I know your course of lise master Taylbee to be as base as the basest, maintained by me, by him by all of us, and a second hand from mistresses, I've their letters here to show?
Why should you be so violent to strip naked

Another's reputation, to the world knowing your own so leprous, beside this ●nai●iey of pearl and those spur-royals came to you fa see y for she broke her faith, and made her soul a strumpet with her body, when she sent those; they were ever justly mine? Pray what moves you sir, why should you shake your head, you're clear, sure I should know you sir, pray are not you sometimes a pandar, and oftener a bawd sir, have I never sinned in your banquetting boxes, your bowers and towers? you slave, that keeps fornication upon the tops of trees, the very birds cannot in gender in quiet for you, why rogue, that goes in good clothes made out of wenches cast gowns.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.p: Nothing goes so near my heart as that?

sp.speaker: Pursenet
sp.p: Do you shake your slave's noddle?

sp.speaker: Tayl.
sp.p: And here's a rascal looked asway too, (Saving the pre, cease of master Goldstone;) a filthy-slimy-lousy-nittical broker, pricked up in pawns from the hatband to the shoestring a necessary hook to hang gentlemen's suits on't it'h air, lest they should grow musty with long lying? which his pawns seldom are guilty off, a fellow of several scents and seeamea; French, Dutch, Italian, English, and therefore his lice must needs be mongrels. why bill money?

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: I am sorry to here this among you, you've all deceived me, truly I took you for other spirits, you must pardon me henceforward, I have a reputation to look to, I must be no more seen in your companies;

sp.speaker: Frip.
sp.p: Nay, nay, nay, nay, master Goldstone, you must not scape so i'faith, one word before you go sir,

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Pray dispatch then, I would not for half my revenues i'faith now, that any gallants should pass by in the mean time, and find me in your companies, nay as quick as you can sir.

sp.speaker: Frip.
sp.p: You did not take away master Bowcer's cloak ●other morning, pawned it to me and borrowed five pound upon't;

sp.speaker: Gold
sp.p: Ha?

sp.speaker: Frip.
sp.p: 'Twas not you neither that finely cheated my little novice at master Primero's house, of a diamond and saphire, and swore they were counterfeit, both glass, mere glass as you were a right gentleman;

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: 'Slife, why were we strangers all this while? s●oot I perceive we are all natural brothers? A pox on●s all are we found i'faith?

sp.speaker: Frip.
sp.p: A cheater?

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: A thief, a lecher, a bawd and a broker?

sp.speaker: Cunst.
sp.p: What mean they to be so merry, I'm afraid they laugh at us and make fools on's.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Push, leave it to me — how now: who would you speak withal?

sp.speaker: Cunst.
sp.p: Speak withal? have we waited all this while, for a suspected thieves

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: How? you're scarce awake yet I think, look well, does any appear like a thief in this company ▪ away you slaves, you stand loitering, when you should look to the common wealth? you catch knaves apace now, do you not? they may walk by your nose, you rascals ?

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Sweet master Goldstone.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: You lacked spirit in your company, till I came among you ▪ here ●ee ●ive on's, let's but glue together, why now the world shall not come between us.

sp.speaker: Pursenet
sp.p: If we be true among ourselves.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Why true; we cannot lack to be rich; for we cannot lack riches, nor can our wenches want, nor we want wenches.

sp.speaker: Prl.
sp.p: Let me alone to furnish you with them.

sp.speaker: Tayl.
sp.p: And me.

lg.l: There's one care past: and as for the knight's daughter,
Our chiefest business, and least thought upon.

sp.speaker: Pursenet
sp.p: That's true i'faith.

sp.speaker: Tayl.
sp.p: How shall we agree for her.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: With as much ease as for the rest: tomorrow brings the night, let's all appear in the best shape we may; troth is, we have need on't, and when amongst us five she makes election, as one she shall choose.

sp.speaker: Pursenet
sp.p: True, she cannot choose.

lg.l: That one so fortunate amongst us five,
Shall bear himself more portly, live regarded,
Keep house, and be a countenance to the rest.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Admiral.

lg.l: For instance, put case yourself after some robbery done
Were pursued hardly; why there were your shelter,
You know your sanctuary: nay say you were taken,
His letter to the justice will strik't dead,
'Tis policy to receive one for the head.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Let's hug thee Goldstone.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: What have I begotten?

sp.speaker: Pursenet
sp.p: What sir?

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: I must plot for you all, it likes me rarely.

sp.speaker: Tayl.
sp.p: Prithee what is't sir?

lg.l: 'Twould strike Fitsgrave pale,
And make the other suitors appear blanks.

sp.speaker: Frip.
sp.p: For our united mysteries.

lg.l: What if we fiu: presented our full shapes
In a strange-gallant, and conceited mask?

sp.speaker: Pursnet
sp.p: In a mask, your thoughts and mine w●te● wins.

sp.speaker: Tayl.
sp.p: So the device were subtle nothing like it.

sp.speaker: Frip.
sp.p: Some post must 〈◊〉 〈◊〉 ▪

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.p: Poet? you'll take the direct l●ne to have us staged? why what lacks Bowser, are you too well, too safe, an absolute scholar, easy to be wrought, no danger in the operation.

sp.speaker: Pursenet
sp.p: But have you so much interest ▪

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.p: What in Bowser? why my least woo● com●●●●● him:

sp.speaker: Tayl.
sp.p: Then no man fitte●.

sp.speaker: Pursenet
sp.p: And there's master Frip too, 〈…〉 sh us of ma●king s●i●e 〈…〉 ●●ow.

sp.speaker: Frip.
sp.p: Upon sufficient pawn I think I can sir▪

sp.speaker: Pursenet
sp.p: Pawn? I●we, here take my ●●aine●pa w●es among brothers? we shall thrive? but we must still expect one ●ongue in five, and think us happy too.

sp.speaker: Go.

div.stage: Enter the virgin between two ancient gentlemen.

lg.l: Grave gentlemen, in whose approved bosoms,
My deceased father did repose much faith
Your dear welcome: pray sit, command music,
See nothing want to beautify this night,
That holds my election in her peaceful arms,
Feasts, music, hymns, those sweet celestial swarms.

sp.p: May you be blessed in this election.
That content, may meet perfection.

lg.head: Hymn.

Voices spring and lift aloud,
Her name that makes the music proud:
This night perfection,
Makes her election:
Follow, follow follow, follow round,
Look you to that, nay you to that, nay you to that:
Anon, you will be found, anon you will be found, anon you will be found.

div.head: Textual Notes
div.p: The textual notes below aim at making textual corrections readable in their immediate context and facilitating access to the source text. A five-dit number preceded by 'A' or 'B' represents an EEBO-TCP filenumber. A notation like "6-b-2890" means "look for EEBO page image 6 of that text, word 289 on the right side of the double-page image." That reference is followed by the corrupt reading. A black dot stands for an unidentified letter, a black square for an unidentified punctuation mark, a diamond for a missing word, and the ellipsis for a short span of undefined length. The corrected reading is displayed as a kewyord in context.
